dialogues.speaker: A DARK RANGE
dialogues.text: of open ground bordered by black pine. Stillness. The shr of insects. Thermal clouds flowing overhead, underlit ora Heat lightning flickers. Thunder sounds distantly. Half-s in the dark, a standing forn.

dialogues.speaker: THE SILHOUETTE
dialogues.text: of a soldier. Helmeted. Unmoving. AGAINST THE NIGHT, . the shape of a hand, bound by rope. Jagged yellow electri branches across the clouds.

dialogues.speaker: THE SOLDIER'S
dialogues.text: features illuminate. The face like a mask, no expression. face of hard plastic. Eyeless.

dialogues.speaker: A WOMAN'S FACE
dialogues.text: in deep shadow. Staring upward in terror and sorrow. A te glinting, spilling slowly.

dialogues.speaker: HER VOICE
dialogues.text: Father...

dialogues.speaker: THE SKY
dialogues.text: boils in fury, clouds churning, as if in God’s answer. Cr streaks of lightning fracture the sky.

dialogues.speaker: HER EYES
dialogues.text: flare, reflecting the flashing sky. A shadow falls over t The heavens rumble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hot rain falling. At the lit entrance, two burly MPs stan sentry. Above them, a legend reading: United States Army Criminal Investigation Command

dialogues.speaker: BURNS, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, this is Major General Joseph Campbell, Commander of the Post at Fort Hadley, Georgia...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Army footage. A general walks among his troops in the Sau Arabian wastelands. Desert camouflage, two stars on his c a huge man, big of bone and breadth, iron visage, intensi

dialogues.speaker: BURNS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (CONT’D) They call him Smokin’ Joe. Forty years of distinguished service. Three tours in ‘Nam. Served in Central Command under General Schwarzkopf... Dust churning, MIAI tanks charging down a sandhill. Turre guns hammering. Mechanized terror.

dialogues.speaker: BURNS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The Gulf War. He stormed Saddam’s Republican Guard with his armored division and helped retake Kuwait City... Towers of black smoke spinning. Rubble. Slain Iraquis lyi like black rags across the desert floor. Then, an airport crowd cheering as the General moves down the ramp of a Bo 707.

dialogues.speaker: BURNS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The General came home a hero. He’s recently accepted an appointment to the National Security Council where he‘ll receive his third star. He’s also considered a contender in the next Presidential campaign... An exterior shot of the White House. Then an office with cadre of administrative and military leaders gathered wit President to effect strategic planning.

dialogues.speaker: BURNS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: With the military drawdown, General Campbell’s election would be vital to our national defense. General Burns sits in silhouette below a projector lens. lights in the room come up. Burns, Commander of the CID, stars on each collar of his battle-dress greens, gazes gr along the length of a conference table.

dialogues.speaker: BURNS
dialogues.text: The directive from Washington is to clear the homicide at Fort Hadley before the General leaves command. Several high-ranking officers and government officials re him solemnly. Colonel Hellmann, Director of Operations, h shorn in a military mohawk, face chisled and seamed, want clarify the directive.

dialogues.speaker: HELLMANN
dialogues.text: When is change of command scheduled, General? Burns considers Hellmann significantly.

dialogues.speaker: BURNS
dialogues.text: In one week, Colonel. Hellmann’s adjutant, Lt. Rogers, looks up from her notati Hellmann tries not to openly scowl.

dialogues.speaker: HELLMANN
dialogues.text: This may be a complex investigation, sir.

dialogues.speaker: BURNS
dialogues.text: And a volatile one, The General has been struck by a tragedy. We don’t want to see it escalating into some kind of scandal that smears the Army or derails his future. Tight containment and rapid closure are imperative... What’s the situation at Hadley? Hellmann restrains his opinion of the timeline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crime scene has been secured by Special Agent in Charge Hawthorne, sir. I’m assembling a team of our top homicide people for deployment.

dialogues.speaker: BURNS
dialogues.text: (frowning) We have no homicide agents assigned to Fort Hadley, Colonel? Lieutenant Rogers slides a computer printout over to Hell He scans it, seeing a name that makes him unhappy.

dialogues.speaker: HELLMANN
dialogues.text: Chief Warrant Officer Brenner. He’s on loan to Procurement and Fraud... Hellmann looks up from the print-out, his eyes flint.

dialogues.speaker: HELLMANN
dialogues.text: He'd be my last choice, sir. Burns stands, expression ominous.

dialogues.speaker: BURNS
dialogues.text: You have the objective. I want the investigation opened immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Headlights flare. A Chevy pick-up truck bounces over a ru track, exhaust rumbling.

dialogues.speaker: ELKINS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (deep South) That’s her up ahead...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Armory sergeant Dalbert Elkins, jittery and sweating, his eroded by hard times, has his eyes riveted ahead.

dialogues.speaker: ELKINS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: HQ -- White Americanist Movement. The driver, Chief Warrant Officer Paul Brenner, stares t the windshield. Rugged, well-built, somewhere in his fort at present he is gritty and unshaven, wearing the same ty battle-dress fatigues and insignia as Elkins.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Looks like they run a pretty tight budget, Elkins. They take in the junked cars and old Harley frames rustin the weeds. Ahead, a flood light burning from a squalid sh Elkins draws feverishly on a cigarette smoked to the filt

dialogues.speaker: ELKINS
dialogues.text: Hell, these old boys put all their money in ordnance. They see what we got, I gar-an-tee, they'll buy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenner and Elkins stand out of the truck, look to the po where several dark shapes lounge in the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY RAY
dialogues.text: How y’all, Dalbert? A backwoods baritone. Elkins squints nervously.

dialogues.speaker: ELKINS
dialogues.text: Up to no good, son. Heh, heh. Johnny Ray saunters off the steps. Bald head, pirate’s be Goes about two-fifty. Made of bricks. An extreme individu

dialogues.speaker: ELKINS
dialogues.text: Johnny Ray, this here’s my partner Armory Sergeant White. We go way back. He’s good wood. Brenner’s eyes cut sharply to Elkins. He looks to Johnny who studies him with keen intensity, his focus resting on name tag.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY RAY
dialogues.text: Love that name. Brenner manages a grin, noting a set of prison-issue ligh bolts emblazoned on Johnny Ray's forearm -- modified Germ declaring allegiance to an Aryan brotherhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice bolts.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY RAY
dialogues.text: You like skin art?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: You bet. Johnny Ray grins, turns. A short, stocky bruiser has appe behind him. Deuce. Shirtless, heavily muscled. Bleary-eye

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY RAY
dialogues.text: Sergeant White likes skin art. Deuce focuses on Brenner insolently. Tattooed vividly acr his chest, a rising eagle, a swastika clutched in its tal

dialogues.speaker: DEUCE
dialogues.text: This here’s a vision for him. Wants to see more, I’1ll drop my pants. Low laughter from the porch. Johnny Ray has a dangerous g in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY RAY
dialogues.text: Deuce is my road dawg. Deuce, high-strung and violent, lunges suddenly, snarling teeth bared. He barks rabidly, snapping at Brenner. An ee and dead-on imitation of a pit bull. More laughter. Deuce growls warningly, glowering. Johnny chuckles cavernously, observes Brenner.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY RAY
dialogues.text: What ya’ll think, White?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Trained him good. Deuce woofs, swaggering over to Brenner’s pick-up, all ey him. He parks himself before a front tire, back to them, open his pants. The drumming of a forceful stream hitting sidewall ensues. He lifts one leg. The porch crew rock in hilarity. Brenner frowns. Johnny R wheezes, his frame shaking.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY RAY
dialogues.text: Ever seen a dawg didn’t like to piss on a tire? Deuce finishes, grinning drunkenly. He ambles away, lean the open trunk of a Cadillac parked beyond the light, lif beer, pops it, raises it to Brenner defiantly. Brenner lo at Johnny Ray unsmilingly.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY RAY
dialogues.text: Show us what you got.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Dalbert. Elkins hustles to the pick-up, drops the gate, snaps back tarp in the bed to expose a heavy BFVS machine gun, ammo belt looped through the breech.

dialogues.speaker: ELKINS
dialogues.text: Combat-loaded seven-six-two coaxial machine gun. Raps-off six-hundred armor-piercing rounds per minute... Got a hot two-dozen of ‘em. Desert Storm’s blown into Georgia, boys. Johnny Ray stares, transfixed. He reaches for it.

dialogues.speaker: ELKINS
dialogues.text: That’s a vehicle-mount item, hoss. Johnny Ray heaves up the heavy rig, steps away from the t He sweeps the barrel over the yard, the bore swinging aro on the two armory sergeants. Both men step back, Johnny R grinning, levels the gun on Brenner’s pick-up. He prepares to fire. There’s no trigger. He looks up at t two armory sergeants accusingly.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Gimme that. Brenner cradles the weight of the gun, angles the sights the hazy shape of a coupe past the lights, strikes the ma fire pad. The weapon rattles deafeningly, flame spitting, streaks o blue tracer ripping a line through the air. The sheet met caves in, glass explodes, chrome crumples, the trunk lid off, turning in the air. Deuce’s mouth is open wide in a that is drowned out by the gunfire. The firing suddenly ceases, ejected casings flying, blue billowing, Deuce’s scream cutting in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ~- HOOOWEEEE! That’s some screamin’ shit, hog! Awed commentary rises from the porch. Deuce blearily stud Brenner's target. His slitted eyes jump wide in recogniti

dialogues.speaker: DEUCE
dialogues.text: Wait a fuckin’ minute... THAT’S MY

dialogues.speaker: RIDE
dialogues.text: His Cadillac comes into focus, blown to scrap-metal. Bren squints toward it, feigning concern.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Aww Jesus... I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: DEUCE
dialogues.text: He smoked my fuckin’ car! Brenner shrugs helplessly. Deuce advances for him, Johnny steps in first. He towers over Brenner.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY RAY
dialogues.text: Who‘'d you brang, Dalbert? Elkins offers a rattled smile. The crew on the porch desc expressions malignant. Brenner edges back.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Okay. I’ve decided I don’t like your attitude. Whole thing’s off. The pack of men start to move on him in unison. Brenner p the gun on them, unused rounds visible in the belt.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Let’s go, Dalbert. Elkins stares at him increduously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenner blasts the vehicle out of the yard, the ring of a men falling behind in the rear window. Elkins rips a hide semi-auto from his waistband, slams it on the dash.

dialogues.speaker: ELKINS
dialogues.text: Man, what the fuck is wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just blew a two-month operation, bonehead!

dialogues.speaker: ELKINS
dialogues.text: Fuck that noise! They were ready to deal! Brenner faces him, snarling.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: They were on to us! You introduced me as Sergeant White! Elkins pauses in confusion.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Look at my name tag, Elkins! Elkins looks at Brenner BDU blouse, the nametag, black le on a white rectangle. It reads “Wright."

dialogues.speaker: ELKINS
dialogues.text: Oh, shit. He stares at his mistake, chagrined. Brenner, disgusted, the truck up onto the dirt road.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: They caught it immediately. It was downhill after that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck roars, clay-dust trailing as it recedes on the

dialogues.speaker: ELKINS, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Damn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenner’s truck rolls up in front of a weather-faded sign reads: "Whispering Pines Trailer Park". He gets out, wear Ahead of him, a few run-down mobile homes among rows of v trailer pads. He walks up a path of rotted planks toward battered Airstream framed against a band of light to the  10 INT. BRENNER’S TRAILER - NIGHT Brenner switches on the light. It flickers weakly, reveal shabby green furniture, plaid carpet, mustard-colored dra He strips off his wet battle-dress blouse, tosses it, mov through the dim clutter to the galley area where he takes bottle of scotch, finds a glass, pours a stiff one.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE LIVING AREA,
dialogues.text: someone is seated in the shadows, motionless, watching hi Brenner stands in the galley. Without seeming to look tow the living area, he finds a second glass.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: You havin’ one of these, Hawthorne? Rodney Hawthorne, Special Agent in Charge of the CID unit Fort Hadley, leans forward. Fifty, weathered, black-skinn hair dashed with gray, eyes jaded. Rumpled suit, tie undo

dialogues.speaker: HAWTHORNE
dialogues.text: Can’t sneak up on you anymore. Brenner tilts the bottle, pours out another drink.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: When could you? He moves into the living area, profers the glass to Hawth Hawthorne takes it. They regard one another. Years of roc history. Friendship.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: This a social visit, sir? Hawthorne drinks his scotch, surveys the trailer’s disord

dialogues.speaker: HAWTHORNE
dialogues.text: Nothin’ social about this place.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: This is my front. Brenner throws some clothes off the sofa, sits down. The men drink, watching each other.  11

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Knew a kid in infantry training who lived in this trailer. Summer of Sixty-Nine. Had a beautiful wife. Hawthorne watches him.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: He gave his all in ‘Nam. Won some medals. Came home, wife was gone. She'd divorced him, married a draft- deferred civilian.

dialogues.speaker: HAWTHORNE
dialogues.text: Ain’t that a bitch.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: What’s really a bitch, dumb bastard re-upped. He’s still in the Army. Hawthorne lifts his glass to Brenner.

dialogues.speaker: HAWTHORNE
dialogues.text: And no smarter. Here’s to him. They drink.

dialogues.speaker: HAWTHORNE
dialogues.text: What's your progress on the weapons operation?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Negligible. But then, so was the operation. Hawthrone stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: HAWTHORNE
dialogues.text: You got your twenty in. Maybe it’s time you cashed out. Brenner considers his drink, the muggy Georgia sky lighti the trailer windows.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Where the hell would I go? Hawthorne shakes his head, sadly.  12

dialogues.speaker: HAWTHORNE
dialogues.text: Two years, Brenner. That’s how long you've been missing in action. Fort Belvoir is done, man. It’s time to move on. Brenner becomes uneasy. It’s a sore subject.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: That’s not why you came over at o- five-hundred, is it, sir? Hawthorne sets his glass down.

dialogues.speaker: HAWTHORNE
dialogues.text: There’s been a murder on the post.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Who was the victim?

dialogues.speaker: HAWTHORNE
dialogues.text: The General's daughter. Brenner is still, jarred by the news.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: General Joe Campbell?

dialogues.speaker: HAWTHORNE
dialogues.text: Affirmative. Captain Ann Campbell was found on Rifle Range Six last night. Strangled. Possibly raped. The magnitude settles on Brenner.

dialogues.speaker: HAWTHORNE
dialogues.text: It’s a hard blow. She was the Golden Girl of Fort Hadley.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: What’s the crime scene like? Hawthorne shakes his head solemnly. Bad. Strange.

dialogues.speaker: HAWTHORNE
dialogues.text: This case is gonna be big, Brenner. Real big... I got you in.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: You what?  13

dialogues.speaker: HAWTHORNE
dialogues.text: As of this moment, you are the lead investigator on a priority homicide. Brenner regards him in disbelief. Brenner’s face

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: You cleared this with Falls Church?

dialogues.speaker: HAWTHORNE
dialogues.text: Colonel Hellmann’s under the gun to get this solved. darkens.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: You know Hellmann won’t let me keep this. He’s got me on back-water assignments. He‘ll send in a hand- picked team.

dialogues.speaker: HAWTHORNE
dialogues.text: I just said I got you in. You’ll have to figure out how to stay in. Brenner tries to calculate the depth of what lies ahead.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Case like this could be career- suicide.

dialogues.speaker: HAWTHORNE
dialogues.text: Unquestionably. Want it or not?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Yeah, I want it. I need a comeback. It's just that... He looks at Hawthorne, his confidence flagging.

dialogues.speaker: HAWTHORNE
dialogues.text: You’ll go up against the same things you went up against last time. Even worse. I can bring someone else in.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: No. Hawthorne stands, a large man, still powerful. He moves p Brenner, stands on the porch gazing out at the steaming p  14

dialogues.speaker: HAWTHORNE
dialogues.text: I’m out of the Army next week.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Is that your choice?

dialogues.speaker: HAWTHORNE
dialogues.text: I’ve given everything I have. There ain’t no more to give. He turns, looks evenly at Brenner. His life spent in serv to something greater than himself.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: You always said, stand by the truth that comes out of an investigation. Never look the other way. And you never did. His eyes convey his respect, and an apology for falling s

dialogues.speaker: HAWTHORNE
dialogues.text: That’s the job, Brenner. Don’t ever let ‘em tell you different. They shake hands in farewell.

dialogues.speaker: HAWTHORNE
dialogues.text: Provost Marshal’s waitin’ for you at the infantry training field. He'll brief you. Good luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major William Kent, Provost Marshal, spit-shined in his w helmet and white pistol belt, stands on the field watchin with icy eyes as Brenner walks toward him from his pick~u Brenner, wearing a blue tropical worsted suit, snaps a sa They have a past, one of restrained animosity. The day ha heavy with humidity.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Major Kent.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Mr. Brenner. You‘re looking worse for the wear.  15

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Thanks. You’re still a marvel of preservation. Were you born or engineered? Kent smiles, his frame conditioned and as hard as his out

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: I was forged, wise-ass. By the U.S. Army. Brenner nods. He knew that. Kent looks at Brenner’s pick-

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: You CID guys goin’ redneck?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: That’s my front.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Now that’s subterfuge.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: You've been studying the vocabulary in your Reader’s Digest.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: I heard you were here, so I wanted some ten-cent words ready... I’m surprised you’re still in business.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: So am I. How’s the baton? Spilled any brains with it lately?

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Oh, sure. You know me.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Yeah. So you'll understand why I’m not anxious to work with you again.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Same here. But it won't be for long. You won‘’t go the distance. Brenner receives the prediction with steadiness.  16

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: You can make book on it when you're off duty. In the meantime, this case is under my control, and you’re here to serve the CID. Kent’s eyes glitter with amused dislike. A boom reverbera from beyond the barracks, the post cannon announcing reve A bugle call, floating from remote loudspeakers. Both men, conditioned by military custom, their eyes on e other, raise their hands in salute. The bugle echoes in t hot stillness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kent’s white Taurus stops in the middle of a road bordere flat vistas. Kent and Brenner get out. They begin walking

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Crime scene's locked down. The SAC sent some warrant officers who seem pretty useless, and I posted MPs. It’s virgin, nothing’s been touched. Except her, of course.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: You've informed General Campbell and his wife of her death? Kent nods, a tic of emotion working at the line of his mo

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: I want to see the General as soon as possible.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: He taking it hard, but I‘1ll see what I can do, The control tower for the firing range rises ahead of the

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: It’s a nasty killing. I hope to God it was committed by a civilian.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Who made positive identification?  17

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: A Sergeant St. John found the body. He was on guard duty with her last night. And I knew her.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Fill me in.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: She was an instructor, Psychological Operations School. West Point. Smart. Good-looking. Standing tall. Poster girl. Put her name on all the duty rosters to set an example. Brenner hears possible invective, files it for later revi Ahead of them,

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Was she armed last night?

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: She had her sidearm. a sand-colored humvee parked at the roadside.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Why was Sergeant St. John out here?

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Captain Campbell left headquarters to check the guard posts and didn’t return. St. John got concerned and tried to locate her. Found her jeep parked here. They approach the humvee. Brenner peers beneath the vehic then touches the exhaust pipe. He moves to the window, lo inside, sees a purse on the seat.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Have you questioned the guard at the nearest post?

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: PFC Robbins. She heard nothing, but saw some headlights. Brenner opens the door, turns the purse over, sorting thr the contents. He lifts a ring of keys.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Detain St. John and Robbins. I'11 want to talk to them. They walk toward the fire control tower where a number of and vehicles are stationed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenner and Kent move past the tower. The firing range co in view, a long expanse of open terrain, black and white markers receding to 500 hundred meters. The sun hovers li a disc of fire. Brenner shields his eyes. A series of berms ahead. Atop each, pop-up targets simula soldiers with rifles. Two MPs stand at parade rest at a b fifty meters ahead. They salute as Brenner and Kent appro Brenner regards the target on the berm, its green plastic staring eyelessly at the sun. He finds it unsettling.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Where are the warrant officers the SAC sent over? Kent looks to the MP’s, one male, one female, both young pale under the shade of their helmets.

dialogues.speaker: MALE MP
dialogues.text: One of ‘em’s losing his breakfast in the bushes, sir. They round the berm. Brenner halts, looks to the dirt ahe Bluebottle flies whip through the air. Her white, naked f glares in the hard light. She lies stripped, on her back, wrists and ankles bound to plastic tent pegs. Captain Ann Campbell. She is no more than thirty. Once qu lovely, now drained, vacant -- the triangle of her pubic her mouth open, tongue and teeth exposed, her eyes rolled into her head. Bitten deep into her neck, a green nylon c knotted tightly. Brenner stares at the body, reminded sharply and painfull another death, another woman. He turns from the image, wa away a few paces, helpless anger filling him. He looks do at her bra, filmy silk, lying cast in the weeds near his  19

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: I should mention, there’s a rape counselor assigned to this case. Kent is behind him.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: The victim doesn’t need counseling, Major. She’s dead. Kent clears his throat. Brenner turns. Special Agent Cynt Sunhill has arrived. She stares at the victim, silent out in her eyes, then at Brenner. Late twenties, trim, attrac without vanity, features shaded by an edge, a resolve wit

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Warrant Officer Sunhill, Mr. Brenner. I was called in from Fort Stewart to assist in this investigation. Brenner assesses her, registering her correctness, her yo and her spiky attitude. She promises to be a pain in the

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: By whom?

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: By Colonel Hellmann's office. She returns Brenner’s examination with her own, her expre indicating unfavorable conclusions.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: You’re a Grade One, Ms. Sunhill. Is Hellmann short-handed? Sunhill’s eyes glint stonily.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: He’s assembling his team from Falls Church. And for the record, when I heard you were here, I asked myself the same question. Kent utters a short, mocking laugh.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Do we know each other?

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Your reputation precedes you.  20

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Hope you’re not here to fax reports on my conduct. You'd never get off the line.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: I’m here because I have specialized training in sexual assault cases.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: This may not be a sexual assault. An investigator's trained not to form conclusions in advance. Says so in the manual. She regards him thinly, her eyes glittering.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Why don’t we get on with it, Mr. Brenner?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: You go first. The body is between them, they both kneel down. Sunhill l at the victim’s naked skin, withering under the heat.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Rigor has commenced. Lividity in the thighs and buttocks... Brenner watches her.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Indicating death occurred when?

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Seven, eight hours ago. Consistent with the report. She pauses, then forces her gaze to the neck, the cord be tightly into it.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Other than the ligature marks made by the rope, there are no apparent bruises, lacerations or bite marks... She glances at him. Brenner is unimpressed. Her face dark and she looks back to the body. She stares at the eyes, t her thumb to an eyelid, hesitantly.  21

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: The corneas have clouded... Small, spotty hemorrhages in the lining of the lids. Presumptive evidence of death by asphyxia.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: What about the hands and nails? Flies snap past her face. Pressing herself, she takes one Campbell’s stiffened hands in her own.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: There are no defensive marks... No blood or dirt under the nails...

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Go on. She lowers her gaze to the abdominal region.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: There's no evidence of semen around the thighs... or the genital area. No outward signs of penetration... Brenner rises, picks up the bra, offers it to her.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: And this?

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: No rips or tears. The clasp is not bent or broken.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: So far, there’s no support for sexual assault. In fact, there are no signs of a struggle. Not on the victim and not in the immediate area. Sunhill stands, keeping her face even.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: You’re saying she disrobed of her own accord, had herself staked out and strangled?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: I'm not saying anything, yet. Thank you, Ms. Sunhill.  22 Brenner crouches, stares into Captain Campbell’s vacant f for a long time. Sunhill watches him, wondering whether s hates him or not. Probably she does. Kent and the two MPs stand sweating silently in the sun. Brenner, eyes fixed, seems to make a resolution. He rises

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Where did Captain Campbell reside, Major?

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Off post in Midland. I’d recommend you clear a civilian search warrant through Chief Yardley. He's a real stickler for jurisdiction. Brenner ignores the advice, scanning the range.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Where's her uniform and dogtags? Her Boots? Pistol?

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: We didn’t find ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Has anyone called in the forensic team from Fort Gillem?

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Major Kent, can you set up a grid search, excluding an area of fifty meters around the body? Have your people to collect anything that’s not part of the landscape.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: This a trash detail?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: It’s an Army detail -- by-the-book -- lots of extra work. You like that. Kent watches him, face blank, the light of hatred in his  23

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: I need Captain Campbell's medical and personnel files sealed and in your office by noon, Major. Tape off her office, impound her humvee, and her private vehicle. Get me a list of everyone who’s been here for disqualifying footprints. And tell Public Affairs we're running a black-out on this. Kent nods curtly, moves off. Brenner looks at Sunhill and sees for the first time how haggard he is.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: How you feeling, Ms. Sunhill?

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: You want the truth?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Hit me.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: I want to nail the motherfucker who did this to the wall. Brenner is taken off guard by the force of her language. starting to reassess her.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: We have something in common. Did you bring a car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A new, convertible Mustang GT moves rapidly down a wide s bordered by Georgia pine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunhill drives, dark glasses on, eyes on the road. Brenne is making notations, a folder on his lap. He stops writin  Sunhill stares He grins. She 24

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Okay. I’ve got a theory. Since we saw no signs of a struggle, we have to consider the possibility Captain Campbell had a preplanned rendezvous with a lover. I’m talking bondage, Ms. Sunhill. Consenting partners.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: That’s a typical male fantasy. She consented to being bound in the dirt like an animal?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: I don’t know that the animal kingdom enters into it. ahead, heat in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: I don’t think you know women, Mr. Brenner. I’m reasonably sure you're not cohabitating with one. ‘s outspoken, smart, aggressive, and she really wants to nail him. Sunhill shakes

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: I did once. But the cave got too cramped. her head to herself.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Thank you. Your analogy helps me understand who I'll be dealing with.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Glad to be of assistance. Pull into that driveway, please. She sees a sign at gated drive: "Victory Gardens". A comp of brick-fascade townhomes.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: I thought you were going by-the-book.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Give or take a chapter.  25 EXT. REAR PATIO ~ CAMPBELL’S UNIT - VICTORY GARDENS - DAY They enter a fenced area. Potted plants, a barbecue, a ch lounge. Brenner presses the buzzer at the kitchen door.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: This is illegal, Mr. Brenner. You‘re jeopardizing the case, not to mention your career. Brenner takes out Campbell’s key ring, sorts through the

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: My career’s been in jeopardy for some time, Ms. Sunhill. The latch clicks, he swings open the door, peers into the inside. He turns to Sunhill.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: You armed?

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Back me up. He moves inside. INT. CAMPBELL’S KITCHEN - DAY Dim light, blinds drawn. Gleaming, sterile. Brenner moves a door at the end of the kitchen, eases it open, looks in closes it. He silently swings a chair out from the table props it under the knob. Sunhill moves up, her automatic

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Basement. We‘’ll check it last. INT. CAMBELL’S BEDROOM/STUDY - DAY Simple and ordinary decor. A tightly-made bed. No frills, sentiment. Order. Brenner stands at an open closet, the r hung precisly with civilian clothes and uniforms.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: This place is sanitized.  26 Sunhill replaces her automatic in her purse. Brenner stro around the room, moves into the bathroom, back out. Walks an alcove containing shelving with books. Studies the tit

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: The complete works of Friedrich Nietzsche... Remember this old favorite? “In revenge and love, woman is more barbarous than man." Sunhill stands at the dresser, examining an open jewelry

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Spare me the misogyny, Mr. Brenner. Brenner shrugs. He turns to the wall nearby, scans the fr plaques, awards, commendations.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: American Red Cross. Victory Gardens Safety Council. Volunteer work at Children’s Hospital... He looks over at her.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: She was perfect in every way. Made in the USA. White-glove immaculate.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Is that a clue? His gaze falls on a flat carrying case on a shelf.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Everything is a clue, Sunhill. The lack of clues is a clue. He unzips the case, exposing a notebook computer.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: I guess I haven’t progressed to that level yet. Sounds Zen.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: This lady had no private life. Does that not strike you as odd..? He considers her buttoned-down aspect.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Well, maybe not.  27

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: That’s very comic... Maybe she was what she was. An unimpeachable and dedicated officer. He removes the notebook computer from the case.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Sorry, I don’t buy it -- I want this. Can you fit it in your handbag?

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: We entered illegally. You know any evidence we find won't be admissible. He crosses to her, standing near and sizing up her handba

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: We admit it into our strategy -- that is great perfume. He hands her the computer. She regards him with vigilance

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: I don't wear perfume.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Now I’m really intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: You‘re not exempt from harassment charges, Brenner. She moves to the door, expression stern.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Let's go down to the basement. Brenner’s eyes light up.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: But we have this great bedroom. Brenner watches her stalk down the stairs, enjoying himse INT. CAMPBELL’S BASEMENT - DAY A flourescent light bursts on. The agents scan the baseme Concrete, washer, dryer. Heating and air conditioning duc  28 On the rear wall, a broom closet and a full-color recruit poster, six-feet high. It features Captain Campbell weari her battle dress uniform and full field gear. They move toward it. Campbell holds a radiotelephone, che her watch, her portrayal sexy, strong, gung-ho. The capti “Synchronize Your Life. See Your Army Recruiter Today."

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: I see a subliminal sexual message here.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Point to it.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Well... it’s subliminal. How can I point to it?

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Your mind runs in very small circles.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: It’s only a thread, Sunhill. Part of a vast fabric. She moves away. Brenner remains, gazing at the woman’s im appreciating her beauty, and wondering who really lived t Campbell's face looms larger, frozen forever in printer's

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I think you better look at this. He turns. She has the broom closet door open, staring wit He moves up next to her. Inside the closet, on a shelf ab the brooms and mops, a black camcorder. It rests on its b turned to the rear of the closet, lens aimed against the Brenner reaches in, slides the camera back, revealing a g the plaster where the lens met the wall. They exchange a and Brenner presses in, peering at the gap.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Is something behind there?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Maybe. It’s dark. I can’t see in.  29 Heavy footsteps shudder the ceiling. The agents whip arou Sunhill wrestles her pistol free. The basement stairs cre A large man in a suit is descending. Brenner nudges the closet door shut. The man stops short, eyes lighting on them. Heavy face, pitted skin. Built lik refrigerator. Sunhill trains her semi-auto on him.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: CID..! Identify yourself! Ignoring her weapon, he raises a police radio-phone, thum on, the line crackling.

dialogues.speaker: YARDLEY
dialogues.text: Big Cat... Where’s the detail I ordered to secure this townhouse over to goddamn Victory Gardens? His face inflames, staring at the intruders, the phone hi

dialogues.speaker: DISPATCHER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: They should be there, Chief. The floor shakes overhead. Two eager and oversized patrol clamber down the stairs, stopping short. They see the age the gun, both grab at their holsters. Yardley growls at t

dialogues.speaker: YARDLEY
dialogues.text: Leave it..! Goddamn g’rillas... Brenner glances at Sunhill. He nods to her weapon. Maybe would be a good idea to put it away. She does. Brenner on hands his wallet, flashing his badge.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Agents Brenner and Sunhill. From Fort Hadley. We’re investigating the homicide of Captain Campbell. Yardley moves into the basement, the patrolmen trailing h He stands across from the agents, clearly restraining a w to do harm. His voice is native Dixie and under hard dure

dialogues.speaker: YARDLEY
dialogues.text: I been notified. Did you obtain a search warrant, Mr. Brenner? Sunhill glances at Brenner, shifting her handbag, the not computer buldging inside it.  30

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: We're working on it. Yardley breathes out a long sigh. His patrolmen take mena positions behind him.

dialogues.speaker: -YARDLEY
dialogues.text: I am very upset that you are here. Sunhill, commanding and smart, steps forward,

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Chief Yardley, this is a priority investigation. It’s important our agencies work in a combined effort on this. Yardley gazes on her curiously. He shakes his head, bemus

dialogues.speaker: YARDLEY
dialogues.text: Women in the Army... He gestures toward the poster of Captain Campbell.

dialogues.speaker: YARDELY
dialogues.text: Look at that. She’s got sixty pounds of field gear. How’s she gonna squat to pee? The patrolmen chuckle appreciatively. Sunhill’s face tigh in anger. Brenner gives her a sidelong glance. She should known better.

dialogues.speaker: YARDLEY
dialogues.text: Come here, Wade. Wade, the larger of the patrolman, assumes a serious, off demeanor, steps next to the Chief.

dialogues.speaker: YARDLEY
dialogues.text: It was your responsibility to seal these premises, am I correct?

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: Chief, I had to get fueled. Yardley shakes his head. No excuses. Wade becomes morose.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. It was.  31

dialogues.speaker: YARDLEY
dialogues.text: And you know we're family, and that I depend on your police-work.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: YARDLEY
dialogues.text: Well, then, there's nothing more for me to verbalize, is there? Wade nods, swallows, closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: WADE
dialogues.text: No, sir. Yardley throws a massive right. Wham. Wade goes down. Har

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Jesus... The agents, stunned, gape at the fallen patrolman. Sunhil handbag slips from her arm, the computer in it clanking a hits the floor. She looks down at it, then to Brenner who staring at her warningly. Yardley sucks on his torn knuck seems not to have noticed.

dialogues.speaker: YARDLEY
dialogues.text: Now... Mr. Brenner. Let me explain somethin’. I work on a cooperative basis with Fort Hadley. But you got to get the proper clearances... Wade groans, lurching to his hands and knees, mouth strea blood. Without looking at him, Yardley lowers a handkerch into his reach. YARDLEY (CONT‘D) Above all, sir, you got to be sure you talk to me before you so much as step in a pile of dogshit that‘s situated on civilian property. Am I makin’ myself understood? Brenner looks to the second patrolman who observes his fa partner neutrally. Apparently, he’s seen it before. Sunhi casually recovers her handbag.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: If I give the wrong answer, does the other guy go down?  32 Yardley stands like a sullen rock.

dialogues.speaker: YARDLEY
dialogues.text: Court order is standard procedure for a search, Mr. Brenner. You file your document, and I'll see that my cousin Judge Dupree expedites it. Meantime, you're trespassin’. Brenner nods, reasonably.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Well, that’s it. The Chief‘s already marked this tree.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: We better go, then. They make their way toward the stairs. Chief Yardley’s fa is set in hard lines, watching them.

dialogues.speaker: YARDLEY
dialogues.text: Mr. Brenner... Brenner turns back to hin.

dialogues.speaker: YARDLEY
dialogues.text: Walk carefully in Midland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunhill pulls out, still shaken. Brenner looks over at he

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: There’s something in that basement.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: He’s going to try and jam us on the warrant.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: We’re going around him.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: This case is doomed.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: The motto of the CID is -- "Do what has to be done." You can look it up in the manual.  re all 33 She glares straight ahead. Brenner scowls She smolders. The car weaves.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: I’1ll say this for you -- you live up to your billing. Arrogant, inflated and careless. at her.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Listen, Sunhill -- I’m at the rank where I get respect. I was in the middle of a shooting war when you were carrying your lunch pail. I’ve spent three-quarters of your age in this outfit.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: (acidly) You're a lean, mean killing machine. Death from the skies. Is that it?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: That’s not bad.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Let's dust this computer for prints, then get a tech on it. And don’t make any plans tonight. We’re going back to the townhouse.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Watch the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An open post. Civilian traffic and Army vehicles. Sunhill’s Mustang moves along a street bordered by WWII-era whitewa bungalows set back on wide dry lawns.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: This unit has a hard disk failure, Mr. Brenner...  34

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Campbell's notebook computer is on, the screen displaying error message. Specialist Dixon, a female agent, sits bef it, tapping the keyboard. Brenner and Sunhill stand over

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: It may have been exposed to heat or excessive vibration... Brenner conveys a dire look to Sunhill.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: I want those files, Dixon. They all stare at the screen dimly.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: I'll have to open the unit and run an internal check. It's gonna take some time.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: That's something we don’t have. Specialist Dixon nods, goes to work.

dialogues.speaker: KENT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Here’s the status: We got the grid search going and sent the dogs out... INT. PROVOST MARSHAL’S BUILDING ~ FORT HADLEY - DAY Brenner, Sunhill and Major Kent move down the faded linol of the hallway, a succession of hard, tattooed kids in ba dress and MP armbands snapping off perfect, vertical salu KENT (CONT’D) Nothing so far... General Campbell's adjutant will contact you regarding a brief interview. And I have Captain Campbell’s files in my office, along with a lecture tape from Psy-Ops.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Who was her CO at the school?

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Colonel Moore. Head-shrinker. And real strange.  35

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Tell him we want to see him today. They walk through a busy office area, turn down another h

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Check. Last item: Colonel Hellmann's in from HQ at seventeen-hundred hours to see the General. You’re to meet him at the airfield. Brenner looks at him. Kent grins. He can hardly wait for outcome. And Sunhill shifts her eyes to him, meaningfully beheading on the tarmac. Brenner is angered.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Probably another commendation. They stop at a door with a heavy glass window. Inside, a looking sergeant with a leathery face sits smoking at a t

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Sergeant St. John. Private Robbins is waiting in another room.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Didn‘t happen to sign a confession, did he? Kent, an old headbreaker, cracks his knuckles, flashes a

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: I could put on some sap gloves and get you one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A violent blur of fangs and fur slams against the wires o cage -- a rhesus monkey, shrieking and yammering, its fan prominent display. Past it, a line of rattling cages occu by crazed primates raising a cacaphonous din. At a lab counter, a man in white, working on a computer a a clutter of electronic equipment. Brenner and Sunhill st in the open doorway.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: (over the noise) Colonel?  36 Colonel Moore peers up at them, lips twisted. He turns a on an amplifier, an ultrasonic wave shudders, the racket the cages instantly ceases. A dozen monkeys stare silentl him, red-eyed with fear and hatred. Moore regards the agents. A short man. High, domed forehe Messianic eyes behind smeared glasses. Lab coat well-spra with monkey piss.

dialogues.speaker: MOORE
dialogues.text: Ultrasonic. They hate that. Brenner and Sunhill stare at the cages, then Moore, unset

dialogues.speaker: MOORE
dialogues.text: The study of induced aggression for war applications.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: How do you induce the aggression?

dialogues.speaker: MOORE
dialogues.text: I‘m getting excellent results with pharmaceutical cocaine. Brenner looks sidelong at Sunhill.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: We're here regarding the murder of Captain Campbell, sir.

dialogues.speaker: MOORE
dialogues.text: (woodenly) Shocking. I’m in a state of profound distress.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Did you have a close relationship with the deceased, Colonel?

dialogues.speaker: MOORE
dialogues.text: I considered her my protege.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: How would you describe her?

dialogues.speaker: MOORE
dialogues.text: Skilled, intelligent, charismatic courageous, and utterly dedicated.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Did she have any good qualities?  37 Moore's eyes become scalpels. The agents are

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: That was a joke, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: MOORE
dialogues.text: This is hardly an appropriate time for levity.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Sorry, sir, the left side of my brain got the better of me... Was Captain Campbell seeing anybody? Dating? A boyfriend?

dialogues.speaker: MOORE
dialogues.text: Captain Campbell considered men weak and contemptible.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: This was a personal view she shared with you?

dialogues.speaker: MOORE
dialogues.text: Professionally. I was her therapist. given pause. Brenner wants some clarification.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: You provided Captain Campbell with psychological counseling, Colonel? Moore's glasses glint frostily, Brenner’s implication evi

dialogues.speaker: MOORE
dialogues.text: You're very quick, aren‘’t you?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: We'll need your transcripts.

dialogues.speaker: MOORE
dialogues.text: There are no transcripts. That was our arrangement.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: That’'s highly unusual, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: MOORE
dialogues.text: The term "unusual" has no application in the frontier of psychology.  38

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Well, we still use it out here in the frontier of homicide, Colonel. And we think it’s unusual that as her superior and her therapist you’re not cooperating in this investigation. A rhesus shrieks out, the agents jump. Moore, unfazed, st before the cage. He and the monkey lock eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MOORE
dialogues.text: You’ve stumbled into the wrong door, Mr. Brenner. When and if you stumble into the right one, the real investigation will begin. The animal shrinks before Moore’s will. Its black, primor eyes recording him: Mortal enemy.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: You're a very spooky man, Colonel. If you're withholding information relevant to this case, I'll make sure you see a court martial. Moore looks up from the cage, triumphant. Man over beast. moves to the amplifier, rests his hand on the knob.

dialogues.speaker: MOORE
dialogues.text: I can’t tell you how frightened I am. If I'm a suspect, arrest me, and I'1i exercise my rights as such -- if not, then I’m extremely busy. He cuts the ultrasonic sound. The monkeys, unleashed, scr out, their angry clamor ricocheting deafeningly off the t The agents, assaulted, retreat. Moore smiles happily, ben to his computer.

dialogues.speaker: A HIGH-DECIBEL WAR SHRIEK
dialogues.text: rings out joltingly, a blood-chilling, piercing, primal s demonic in its fury. It issues from a woman’s open mouth, teeth flashing, eyes aflame.  39

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN ANN CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: ends the shriek, shockwaves reverberating. Her face insta composed. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Good morning...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stands on a rostrum, immaculate in battle fatigues, g out over an audience of stunned soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Today we discuss applications for psycholgical warfare -- how we can use it to loosen the sphincters of opposing forces... Tense laughter. Campbell smiles again, assured, poised, s

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Psychological warfare plants the poisonous seeds of doubt. It paves the way for fear and panic. Deep, paralyzing, free-floating anxiety... She stares out over the audience.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: That same fear and panic, instilled in a troop commander can cause even more havoc. Our objective is to render leaders useless. How..? By knowing our enemies. Exploiting weaknesses. Undermining strengths. Manipulating... Mind~fucking... CAMPBELL'’S IMAGE becomes grainier, playing from a television screen.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Excuse, me -- mind-fudging -- because we're on tape today... Audience laughter. Her face in close-up. Her eyes hazardo  40

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER AND SUNHILL
dialogues.text: sit in his darkened office, staring at Campbell’s image o screen. The screen blanks, they are still, the VCR rewind

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: That was a dangerous woman.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: I like her. Brenner looks over at her. She looks back at him, unblink

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An eight-passenger C-21A dips down from the purple clouds skims the runway, turbo-fan engines screaming. Dust explo from its landing gear. Brenner and Sunhill stand at the edge of the tarmac, watc

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Der Oberfuhrer has arrived.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: I have a feeling this is where we part company. They hold a stare, hers confident, his calculating. The p taxis toward them, heat shimmering off on the runway.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t rock the boat, Sunhill. Right now, it’s you and me, and we can solve this. It would doa lot for your career. Know what’s gonna happen if Hellmann puts his team on? Bunch of male hotshots? You'll end up serving the coffee. She regards him uncertainly. He nods. Something to think

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel Hellmann moves down the ramp, bearing a valise an severe expression. His adjutant, Lt. Rogers, following hi Brenner and Sunhill salute. Hellmann ignores Brenner, giv Sunhill a charming smile.  41

dialogues.speaker: HELLMANN
dialogues.text: Ms. Sunhill. I’m glad you were able to transfer to this case.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Sir. He transfers his gaze to Brenner, charm drained.

dialogues.speaker: HELLMANN
dialogues.text: I see that you’ve been debauching yourself.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: It’s called lack of sleep, sir.

dialogues.speaker: HELLMANN
dialogues.text: I'm going to remedy that. I intend to replace you. Brenner subverts an urge to kill him. A staff car is pull up nearby. Hellmann's transport to the General's house. T group starts walking toward it.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. But I don’t think that would be wise.

dialogues.speaker: HELLMANN
dialogues.text: Why wouldn't it be wise? They pass a line of dark and lethal AH-64 Apache helicopt

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: This is a very sensitive case, sir. And our findings so far say it’s gonna get a lot more sensitive. A team will step all over it. You need a low-profile, a delicate hand.

dialogues.speaker: HELLMANN
dialogues.text: Delicacy isn’t a word that occurs to me when I think of you, Mr. Brenner.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: That’s where Ms. Sunhill comes in, sir. My expertise, her finesse... Sunhill throws a stabbing look at Brenner.  42

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: This case gets very tangled, Colonel. We‘re already untying the knots. We can bring it home. In record time.

dialogues.speaker: HELLMANN
dialogues.text: Is this a clumsy attempt to deceive me, Ms. Sunhill? They both look at her.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: We have some... strong leads, sir.

dialogues.speaker: HELLMANN
dialogues.text: Twelve hours into the investigation, I’d expect nothing less. I'm certain whatever leads you have will be put to good use by the incoming team, of which you will be a part. Sunhill bleakly considers her part with the team. They ar at the staff car. The driver salutes.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Sir, we expect a major break in the investigation by tonight. Hellmann turns, his full attention on her. She’s in it no

dialogues.speaker: HELLMANN
dialogues.text: A major break? Brenner’s eyes urge her to plunge ahead.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. It’s... going to blow this case wide open. Hellmann stares measuredly at her.

dialogues.speaker: HELLMANN
dialogues.text: I’m leaving at o-six-hundred. You have til then to substantiate that. He pauses before entering the car, turning to Brenner.  43

dialogues.speaker: HELLMANN
dialogues.text: If it goes unsubstantiated, you, Mr. Brenner, will answer to a board of inquiry, seven steely-eyed officers who will eat your ass for lunch... Long overdue, in my opinion. He closes the door. The agents stand in the twilight watc the car drive away.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: You’re coming around.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: We have maybe twelve hours. What if there isn’t anything behind that basement wall?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Then I’1ll have some company at the top of Hellmann’s shit list.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Why are you on that list? They begin toward her car. She stares insistently at him.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: It’s under the bridge, Sunhill.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: That’s not good enough. Brenner keeps walking. She grabs his arm, halting him, ey intense, on his.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: You were a top agent a few years ago. What happened? Brenner frowns, looking out over the airfield, heat risin the red twilight.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: There was a case. A captain who was beating his wife up on a regular basis. I had enough for an arrest -- felony battery. She waits for more. Brenner is not forthcoming.  44

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: That’s it?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: No. She told me she was terrified he’d end up killing her. But the captain had an outstanding record and some high-ranking friends. It was strongly suggested I should act in the best interests of the Army and drop it. She surmises the rest from his grim profile.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: But you didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: No. I did. And ten days later he beat her to death with his hands. He faces her, his eyes stark. An Army chopper rams overhe lights blinking in the red sky.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: There was an inquiry. Same people who wanted the case dropped turned around and helped rake me over the coals. Hellmann was one ‘em. But they were right about one thing -- I didn’t do my job. Sunhill watches him somberly.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: It comes down to this -- The Army’s all I have. I didn’t want to risk it. So I went along, and she lost her life for it. I’m only on this case because an old friend threw me a rope. He moves for the car.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: I going all the way on this, Brenner. Can I count on you? He turns, considering the question.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: I don’t know.  45 EXT. CAPTAIN CAMPBELL’S TOWNHOUSE - NIGHT Lightless windows. Police tape. Parked in the shadows by front door, a patrol car. Two officers behind the windshi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunhill watches him through the slats of the privacy fenc Behind her, Brenner has a penlight trained on the police barring the kitchen entry. He takes out a screwdriver, st prying the lock on the sliding glass door. INT. BASEMENT - CAMPBELL’S TOWNHOUSE - NIGHT The penlight glares. They stand before the open broom clo the camcorder illuminated. Brenner slides the camera off the shelf. He opens it and both look down at the film cassette still inside. He hand to Sunhill, uses his penlight to probe the hole where the met the wall. He ducks out of the closet, searching along the wall with light. It hits Captain Campbell's poster, her features ee illuminated. He runs his light over the poster frame.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Okay. He is staring at one side of the frame, slightly ajar fro wall. He takes hold of it and the poster swings out on bl hinges. Revealing a doorway. The agents gape inside, Brenner's penlight piercing the b

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: My God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenner snaps a light switch. The agents enter slowly, ta the room in, astonished. The furnishings and color scheme are whorehouse-chic. Ove four-poster bed, a huge, violent, acrylic depicting a bul like satyr and a nymph in the throes of thundering copula  46

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: I don’t like where this is going.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Welcome to the lower-depths. Brenner moves past a T.V. and VCR on a dresser, opens the on an antique wardrobe. A rack of specialty clothes. Leat and red lace. Spiked heels, riding crops.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ... Nurse. Dominatrix. Lingerie Queen. Sunhill pulls out a drawer, her eyes widening. Neatly sto within, tools for erotic pleasure: oils, lubricants, mana devices of rubber and metal, obsessively ordered, categor

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: This place is set-up for traffic. What was she doing? Running a bordello right under the nose of the U.S. Army? Sunhiull is bewildered, and angered. She rips open the ne drawer -- Triple xX-videos, alphabetized. Hauls out anoth spilling a heap of crisply laundered sheets and towels. S stares down at them, resentfully.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: It isn’t about sex. Everything's organized, clinical. It’s cold. Why did she do it? Brenner sees her conflict.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: She had some problems. This is where they climbed out. She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: I‘d say this qualifies as that major break, wouldn’t you? EXT. CAMPBELL‘S TOWNHOUSE - NIGHT A bright flashlight beam pierces the night. A big silhoue moves up behind it. Wade, Yardley’s patrolman, mouth brui  47 He ambles along the front of the townhouse, throwing his on the windows and shrubbery. He turns at the building's and begins toward the rear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenner is reflected in a wall-sized mirror, holding a pe the glass. He turns to Sunhill.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: This is two-way. She was rolling home videos.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Starring who, Brenner?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: My guess is, the armed forces. Let me have that cassette, Brenner moves next to her, turns on the TV and VCR. Sunhi gets uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: You’re going to run that now?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Preview. Reluctantly, she gives the cassette to him. He slides it

dialogues.speaker: THE SCREEN
dialogues.text: blips on, a poorly-lit recording cuts in. Two naked, heav bodies engaged in savage intercourse. The man, on the bot not clearly seen. The woman, on top, stunningly identifia Captain Ann Campbell. Full breasted, hair tangled, riding partner on the four poster bed like a banshee. The sequence cuts out. Another interlude jogs in. The lig bad, but not so bad that Campbell can’t be identified aga receiving the strokes of a lash held by a different man, and lean and standing half-out of the len’s view.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Turn it off.  ss 48

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. This last guy looks familiar. The action reverses as Brenner rewinds. He freezes the fr on the the man with the lash, shirtless, face in profile, features defining into sudden, shocking clarity.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: (jarred) Brenner... She and Brenner stare, dumbfounded.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Major Kent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wade stands at the sliding glass door, frowning, his ligh the jimmied latch. Beyond the patio fencing, a car starts Wade stamps over to the gate, ramming through it. Glares at a Mustang, lights off, speeding away across the lot. H jerks his police radio up, dashing for the front of the u

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mustang shoots down a long empty strip of asphalt bor by a black wall of trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunhill drives swiftly. Lights hit her rear view mirror. stares into it. Closing in on her rear at high speed, a l rust-colored vehicle.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: There’s a truck behind us. Brenner turns around as the truck looms up in the back wi It rides their bumper, then pulls out to pass, engine roa The agents look over to it as it comes up even. A big, de flatbed, two men in the cab, the driver huge, the passeng leaning out his window, leering at them with a strange le harness clamped to his face.  49 The truck pulls ahead. Chained to the back, a greasy pit lunging against his chain and barking dementedly. The fla shoots up the road, exhaust ripping the air, harness-face out his window, his jubilant howl trailing. Sunhill swerves the car, jarred by the exhibition.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Good lord. Who the hell is that? Brenner stares ahead grimly. He knows who it is.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Brenner, that man had something on his face.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: He’s wearing a dog muzzle.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: What? She looks at him, perplexed.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: You had to have been there. The flatbed, far ahead, disappears around a bend in the r

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mustang blows past a roadsign: "Leaving Fort Hadley". sweeps into the bend the flatbed vanished around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunhill cranks around the turn, accelerates. As she does, road ahead comes into view, and they both gape at the whe farming implement that rushes up in the headlights, a bla disk harrow pulled broadside in their path. Sunhill screams. Brenner flinches. She jogs the wheel rig

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brakes scorch, the car plows sideways toward the mach in screen of tire smoke, narrowly avoiding the blades, le the road, cleaving a wire fence, slamming through brush, hand wheels dropping into a drainage ditch.  50 The car skids aslant, metal shearing, sparks flying, come last to a grinding halt under the trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The interior turned at an angle, the driver’s airbag infl Sunhill slides out from behind it, tumbles against Brenne is slung tight against his seatbelt. He looks dazedly out window, the bottom of the ditch a foot and half from his In the hot quiet, a backwoods baritone floats from the tr

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Tear ‘em up! Clawed feet scrabble. Something is bounding through brush moving rapidly toward them. Brenner and Sunhill stare out window, panic in their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Brenner. The dog. Sunhill lifts herself off Brenner. He struggles furiously free himself as the sound of cracking brush and pounding closes in. : Brenner’s arm is pinned by his weight. He tries to wrench loose. A malevolent rumble. They freeze. Above them, in the dark at the top of the ditch, the pit wedge-headed, fangs glistening. It scans them with a kill eyes, shoulders and chest bunched with muscle.

dialogues.speaker: SUNEILL
dialogues.text: Brenner... do something. The dog’s heavy jaws drop open, strings of spittle suspen

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Nice doggy... The animal leaps in flying snarl. Brenner wrests his serv automatic from his shoulder holster. The gun cracks, buck in his hand, the dog yelps, slain in mid-leap. It soars o them and thumps solidly against the roof of the car. Someone screams from the trees, an anguished, vengeful ho A deeper voice is heard in reprimand. The doors of a vehi clunk closed, a big engine fires. The flatbed pulls away, sound of it receding.  51 Brenner and Sunhill sag, drained. In a few moments, the s of another vehicle is heard. They raise up, listening, as swerves suddenly off the asphalt, bumps slowly up through weeds, stops nearby. The door opens, footsteps crunch clo Brenner angles his pistol toward the top of the ditch. A of boots appear above them. Chief Yardley squats down wit flashlight, examing the Mustang's roof.

dialogues.speaker: YARDLEY
dialogues.text: Damn, that’s an ugly dog. Anybody hurt down there? The light probes Brenner’s face.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Nope. dust chillin’.

dialogues.speaker: YARDLEY
dialogues.text: Mr. Brenner, you and the lady are both very lucky. This could have been a serious accident.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: We had an airbag.

dialogues.speaker: YARDLEY
dialogues.text: Who put this harrow out here in the road like this?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Clem, the mad rutabaga farmer. A delirious laugh escapes Sunhill. Yardley’s eyes are sli

dialogues.speaker: YARDLEY
dialogues.text: I tried to warn you about Midland. Folks hereabouts are touchy. Is there anything you might have done that offended someone?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: I’m searching my mind...

dialogues.speaker: YARDLEY
dialogues.text: We need a cohesive strategy here, Mr. Brenner. A cooperative plan to achieve our mutual objective, which is findin’ the scum killed Miss Campbell.  52

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: I couldn’t have said it better.

dialogues.speaker: YARDLEY
dialogues.text: Here’s my proposal. You give me what you got, I‘ll give you what I’ve got. We'll trade information. How’s that sound? Brenner starts to tell him. A vehicle roars by on the hig at high speed. Yardley jumps up with his radio.

dialogues.speaker: YARDLEY
dialogues.text: (into radio)

dialogues.speaker: BACK HERE
dialogues.text: No reponse. Yardley sprints away in the dark. Brenner hau himself out of the window, kneels in the ditch to help Su through. She drags her purse out, they stand. Yardley is a dark shape on the road, waving his arm, shou into his radio, the flashing red police lights of the veh dwindling.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Chicken-fried-piece-of-shit.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Let’s get the hell out of here.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Good idea. They climb out of the ditch, fade into the cover of the w EXT. PROVOST MARSHAL’S BUILDING - FORT HADLEY - DAY A row of identical white MP cars. Major Kent, blouse alre plastered with sweat, stands at the door of one of them. He turns to the sound of thumping exhaust. A pick-~up gli up behind him. Brenner leans out. The two men stare at on another.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Hot. Brenner shuts his truck off, gets out, saunters over.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: What’s on your mind, Brenner?  53

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Thought we'd talk.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Talk about what?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Let’s talk about Captain Campbell. Kent assesses him. Brenner has something.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: All right. Captain Campbell: She was an inspiration to us all.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Wholesome. Clean of mind and limb.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Virtuous. Godly. The angel of the armed forces.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Sanctified.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Duty, honor and integrity.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: And you were fucking her. Kent sighs, a long, tired exhalation.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: I was seeing her.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: You were ‘seeing’ her?

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: (resigned) I was fucking her.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: You were lashing her with a whip.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Let's don’t get personal. He glowers, uncovered, grimly considers his options.  54

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: It was a fling ~- all right -- it was a full-blooded affair. Christ, she was twenty-nine, I'm fifty-two. What man could’ve turned that down?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: This isn’t good, Major.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: I know. But I wasn’t the only one. She was a whore, Brenner.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Give me some names.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: I didn’t stand in a line with them. Brenner is ominously silent. Brenner stares Brenner shakes

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: All right. Yardley. The Chief of Police... I had nothing to do with her murder.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: You're a prime suspect. Where were you between o-twenty-two and o- twenty-four hundred hours that night?

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Home in bed.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Your wife can verify that?

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: (bitterly) No. She’s on an extended visit with her parents. at him. Kent struggles to hold in his temper.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: You‘ve got me wrong on this. I'm not in the best of shape right now. One man to another, hold off for a while. I can help you find the real culprit. his head.  55

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Thirty years as a military policeman in this division, Brenner... I want to leave with something.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Major. Kent becomes deadly silent. Brenner walks to his truck, g in, starts it. He looks at Kent as he rolls by. Kent stan watching him, forbiddingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenner’s truck moves past an MP checkpoint. It drives pa long row of cars, vans belonging to the forensic team. Ah Sunhill, waiting for him outside a rental car. Brenner pa gets out, moves up to her. M-16 gunfire crackles from nea

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: We have an appointment with General Campbell at eighteen-hundred hours.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Good,

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: What did Kent give you?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: He’s coming unwound. He denied any part in the killing, threw Yardley at me.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Kent. Yardley. Moore. And how many others? Any one of them could’ve had a motive. They begin walking toward the fire control tower. Beyond the peak of the team’s canvas pavillion.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: I got the report to Hellmann. Over breakfast at the OC. He said he'd review it, but I didn’t like the look in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Maybe his croissant was stale.  56 Sunhill regards him tensely.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: We're in trouble, Brenner. Even if he keeps us. This case is not a straight line. It’s warped. We’ll never solve it before the General leaves command.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Relax, Sunhill. We have seven days.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Six. Brenner frowns.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Who's counting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenner and Sunhill move down a path of tarpaulin toward berms where the huge, green, open-sided pavillion is erec over the site of the murder. Forensic staff swarm the area, taking casts of indentatio firing cameras, scouring staked-off quadrants on their ha and knees to collect evidence. Officer in Charge Cal Seiver approaches them. A well-trai neurotic, short and bald, wearing a dusty BDU cap and for piecing together chaos.

dialogues.speaker: SEIVER
dialogues.text: The entire fucking world danced around the body, Mr. Brenner.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Agent Sunhill, Chief Warrant Officer Seiver.

dialogues.speaker: SEIVER
dialogues.text: Pleased to meet you, Ms. Sunhill.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Any non-military footprints? Seiver looks at their shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yours and hers. I'll need the shoes for disqualifying. Everything else is boots. Forensics ain't easy when everyone's wearing the same fucking thing. He takes off his cap, mops sweat from his bald head.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: New memo from the Pentagon, Seiver. You are not short and bald. You're a vertically challenged man of scalp. Seiver looks at Sunhill.

dialogues.speaker: SEIVER
dialogues.text: You have to work with this guy? I extend my sympathies.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Gratefully accepted... Did you find any indications of a sexual assault, Mr. Seiver?

dialogues.speaker: SEIVER
dialogues.text: We ran some tests. Pathologist will have the final word, but my take on it is, she wasn’t raped. Brenner gives Sunhill a meaningful glance.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: What else do you have at this point?

dialogues.speaker: SEIVER
dialogues.text: We dusted for latent prints, vacuumed for trace evidence, analyzed for tool marks, and ran some seriology tests. To answer your question, we have shit at this point. Brenner glances at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: All right. We requisitioned an empty hangar over at Jordon Field. You can set up your lab and offices there.

dialogues.speaker: SEIVER
dialogues.text: Fuckin’ spectacular.  58

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: All reports and inquiries go to me, sealed and confidential. Instruct your people not to talk to anyone, particularly the Provost Marshal. Seiver nods, registering the implication here.

dialogues.speaker: SEIVER
dialogues.text: How’d you pull this case, Brenner?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Dumb luck. INT. - BRENNER’S TRUCK - ROAD - FORT HADLEY ~ EVENING Brenner drives, Sunhill jots in her notebook, evergreen b

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Okay. No signs of struggle, no signs of rape. Consensual. Orchestrated. Ritualistic... What’s that suggest?

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: A sacrifice. He turns to her, struck by the revelation.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: A sacrifice... That’s dead-on. But to what?

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: And by whom? Our killer’s hiding in a suspect list that’s starting to read like the phone book.
