dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: We’ll have to flush him out.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: We throw out the rules.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Oh, God. Brenner loosens his tie.  59

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Had a homicide suspect once. I knew he did it. He knew he did it. But we had no physical evidence. He was carrying this terrible secret around. Went to the post chapel every Sunday.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: I know -- you planted the evidence. He gives her a narrow look.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: I capitalized on his sense of guilt. Got a confession.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: How did you get a confession?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: In the confessional... I sat in for the chaplain.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: You’ve got to be kidding.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: The man bared his soul to me. I got everything. Then I held my badge up to the grill. He was expecting Hail Marys... It would have been thrown out in court, but after that, how could he deny it? So he signed the real thing.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: That's reprehensible.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Of course it is. So was the crime. I just leveled the playing field. And that’s my point. That‘s how we get this guy. Sunhill eyes, him, envisioning the end of her career. Bre slows the truck. Ahead, a drive shaded by magnolias, a wo marker reading: “Residence of General Joseph Campbell". They turn up the drive. Coming into view, an antebellum r of the Old South. White columns, white iron balustrades, declining behind the roofline.  —_ 60 EXT. PORCH - GENERAL‘S RESIDENCE - EVENING They stand on the porch. Brenner chimes the bell.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: I’m nervous as hell.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Let me do the talking.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: That's what I’m nervous about. The door opens. A young lieutenant appears. Handsome, bro shouldered. His name tag reads: “Elby".

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Warrant Officers Brenner and Sunhill to see General Campbell.

dialogues.speaker: ELBY
dialogues.text: I’m the General’s adjutant. Chief of Staff Colonel Fowler wishes to speak with you beforehand. INT. GENERAL’S RESIDENCE - EVENING The agents follow Elby to a waiting room. He departs. The remain standing, tense, eyeing the period-style furnishin In the doorway, Colonel Fowler, in dress-greens with colo eagles and insignia of the General Staff. Imposing and ca hardened, a well-used weapon of a man. He moves in, his n tag introducing him. Brenner and Sunhill salute.

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: Please be seated. They take seats. Fowler sits across from them. He examine them sternly, his eyes recording every detail, the slash an old battle scar angling from ear to jawline.

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: Forgive the recon. I wanted to see who was coming into the General’s house. It’s ingrained, singling out friends from enemies. His gaze meets Brenner’s.  61

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Hope you're not going to radio in the rockets, sir.

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: Why? Can‘’t you duck an incoming?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: With a day’s advance notice. Fowler sits back, considering him.

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: Hundred and Ninety-Fourth battalion. Bantangan Peninsula. LZ Dotty. You received a bronze star for carrying a wounded soldier out of a minefield... Sunhill looks at Brenner. He is staring at Fowler.

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: Apparently, you capitalized on your weak knees, Mr. Brenner -- Airborne School, Ranger School. Two decades in the CID. Commendations. Awards for valor. A candidate for Master Grade Five... and then you fell off the map... Fowler’s eyes veer to Sunhill.

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: Agent Sunhill... Masters degree in Psychology. Advanced training, FBI Academy. Three years as an enlisted criminal investigator specializing in rape crimes. Solid performance, rapid advancement. Experience with homocides -- limited. He pauses, both agents watching him warily.

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: I've opened your files. It’s crucial we have the best qualified people on this. So I’ll be blunt. Is that who you are?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Sir, do you want great reviews or do you want results?  A savage wrath 62

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: My requirements are straightforward, Mr. Brenner -- Someone has violated the very core of this division, and I want him found. ices his eyes. Brenner meets them.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: We’re going to have an arrest before the General leaves command, Colonel. Brenner glances at Sunhill.

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: Elaborate.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Sir, how well did you know Captain Campbell?

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: Well enough to deliver a eulogy when her family buries her.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Did she have a good relationship with her father, Colonel? Fowler considers his words.

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: General Campbell is an extraordinary soldier, Ms. Sunhill. His daughter was strung with the same steel. She was in awe of him, driven to live up to his example.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: The fact of the matter is, Colonel, she was out of control. Fowler stares at her unblinkingly.

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: Yes. She was endangering her career as an officer.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: And the General’s.  63

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: And the General's. Everyone is silent.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: You have the floor, sir.

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: Captain Campbell was headstrong and willful. Her conduct off-duty had become intolerable. I conducted a surveillance of her activities at the General’s request. It confirmed the worst. She was consorting with many men.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Were you aware they included Provost Marshal Major Kent? The Chief of Staff regards him gravely.

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: Major Kent’s discharge is pending.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: I’d like to request those files, sir.

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: Major Kent has served this division with extreme loyalty. I don’t believe he committed this crime, and I would be reluctant to release them.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: If that were the case, sir, I’d have to subpeona them.

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: You may well, Mr. Brenner. I think your perpetrator is outside the military. 1’11 stand by my men until the evidence tells me otherwise. Brenner nods, he admires the attitude. Fowler smiles, war cutting through his harsh exterior.

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: This case seems to be in competent hands. Whatever else you need, let me know. I’11 do what I can.  64

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir. Fowler rises. The agents rise.

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: We'll see the General now. No need to salute, quick condolences. Keep it short. INT. GENERAL’S DEN - DAY The agents enter. A dim chamber of polished wood and leat the drapes drawn. A desk lamp glowing from the dark. Behi the desk, a large man in shadow.

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: Warrant officers Brenner and Sunhill, General. Major General Joe Campbell walks forward, wearing battle- and a chest-full of medals. His face is craggy, his hand as he extends it out.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Our deepest condolences, sir.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Thank you. Please be seated. Voice melancholy, eyes glazed with grief. He nods to Fowl who leaves silently. They all take chairs.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Colonel Fowler and I have served in the Army together for forty-three years. We were boys in Korea, men in Viet Nam, elders in the Gulf. I suppose as war becomes an antiquated notion, so do we. His smile is pained. Brenner and Sunhill smile back polit Campbell looks like a fierce Scottish clan chief, a broad wielder. His smile leaves him.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: What’s the objective of this meeting?  65

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Sir, to collect information that will lead to a swift arrest.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Then you have my full cooperation. He gazes on Sunhill. It is evident that he sees in her yo and attractiveness his own daughter.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Sir, did you see your daughter often?

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Not infrequently. We were to have breakfast the morning after she was... She never showed, of course. He stares hollowly into her absence.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: What was the nature of that meeting, sir? The General reflects, sadly rueful.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Frankly, my daughter required a bit of a dressing down. She was given to obstinate behavior on occasion. I’d given her an ultimatum. Change her ways or incur paternal hellfire. He smiles at her, brokenly.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Perhaps you've experienced that sort of episode yourself. The question triggers a tight reaction.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. My father was a command sergeant and a disciplinarian of the highest order. Brenner sees animosity flicker in her eyes. The General g away from her.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Well... She’s gone to us now.  66 He sits without moving or speaking. Staring. A long silen passes. On the desk behind him, a decanter of liquor, nea empty, a half-filled glass.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: I have to ask this, sir: where were you on the night of her death? Campbell stirs himself.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: At my office at HQ. I was working late with Colonel Fowler.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: What time did you leave, sir?

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: At about twenty-three-hundred hours.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: General, did you have have any contact whatever with your daughter on that night? Campbell’s eyes turn clouded, desconsolate.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: No. The General slowly rises. They rise. This session is over

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Sir, is there anything we can do for you? He looks down on Brenner darkly, his voice very low.

dialogues.speaker: GENERAL CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: Find the son of a bitch who killed her. EXT. GENERAL CAMPBELL’S RESIDENCE - EVENING Lieutenant Elby closes the door behind the agents. They s off the porch, move toward Brenner’s truck.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Maybe he’s the son of a bitch.  67

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: What‘s wrong with you? You saw the way she was killed. The General is clearly shattered by this.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: He’s still accepting his appointment to the Council. He hasn’t said he’s out of the next Presidential race.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: This father-daughter thing’s really hitting a nerve, isn’t it? His words elicit a withering look.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: It's obvious Captain Campbell was repressed by this man her whole life. He pushed her down and she was going all out against it. That’s the reason she was killed. Brenner stares at her. They stop at the truck.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Don‘t let your personal biases get in the way, Sunhill. You’ll start forcing the pieces to make ‘em fit.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: My personal biases? This is a men’s club. I’m the woman, Brenner. It’s called objectivity.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Better come up with more than that. She looks at him meaningfully.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The slam of gloves against a heavy bag. Sunhill is throwi swift, solid series of combinations into the canvas, her clothes sweated through. She huffs out, her blows aggress her teeth clenched in anger.  68 Brenner, in a nicely tailored gray suit, stands in the do beyond, watching her. Sunhill turns, She strips off She picks up a

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Anybody I know? breathing hard.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Chances are good. her gloves. She looks like she hasn’t slept.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: I went through her files last night. All of them. Exemplary history. Until you go back to the beginning... towel, Brenner watching her.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: West Point. Evaluation on admission was good. But third year evaluation plunged. Apparently, she fell apart.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Fell apart?

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Grades, attitude. She had a series of consultations with an Army dector named Zaccardo. The records are missing, but his conclusion’s on the evaluation -- stress syndrome.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: And you don’t buy it?

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: I think there’s something else here. This woman was acting out her anger, rage. Maybe there was an incident, some kind of traumatic event. It’s worth tracking down. Brenner considers it. Her eyes are on him, intense, full conviction.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: I understand her, Brenner. I know who she was,  69

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seiver’s forensic operation is installed within the caver space, arched girders soaring high overhead, the commotio his staff echoing. Sunhill and Brenner move past Captain Campbell's humvee, of bulletin boards, photos, maps, diagrams, computers, ph vast tables of bagged and tagged evidence. They enter the lab section. Seiver stands before three co urns, irritably trying to get half a cup filled.

dialogues.speaker: SEIVER
dialogues.text: You want me to go without sleep, get me some fuckin’ caffeine.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Get me some results, I’11 buy you an expresso machine.

dialogues.speaker: SEIVER
dialogues.text: Start shopping. Item one: Captain Campbell’s clothes and dogtags were recovered at Range Six. They were found in a plastic trash bag on the roof of a latrine. They walk to another section of the lab. Corkboard partit display a detailed diagram of the range, bristling with m colored pinheads designating prints. A table holds dozens numbered plaster castings of impressions.

dialogues.speaker: SEIVER
dialogues.text: Item Two: Lots of tracks. We matched up the ones we thought were pertinent and fed everything into the computer. Seiver stands at a computer monitor, hammers some keys, b up a graphic image. Footprints. They step across the scre in a described pattern, as if an invisible being were lea tread marks in its wake.

dialogues.speaker: SEIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That gave us the print sequence for individual tracks. We analyzed the ones closest to the body... The screen brings up a three-dimensional image, two bootp created with netted contour lines, one overlaying the oth  70

dialogues.speaker: SEIVER
dialogues.text: This is Sergeant St. John’s boot and the print it overlays is Major Kent's boot. Indicating Kent arrived on the scene before St. John's discovery.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Is that positive?

dialogues.speaker: SEIVER
dialogues.text: I’m surmising. We have two military bootprints of the same make and same tread depth, made within hours of each other. If you want positive, I’1l send the photos and casts to an expert.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: I want positive. Get it on a plane.

dialogues.speaker: SEIVER
dialogues.text: Right. I have two sets of bootprints here that haven't been ID'd yet. Brenner canvasses the area. He sees a junior agent strugg with a stack of reports. He whistles shrilly, waves him o

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR AGENT
dialogues.text: Sirt

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: We need some boots for the lab. The Post Commander’s. The Chief of Staff’s. Colonel Moore at Psy-Ops.

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR AGENT
dialogues.text: Yes, sir... General Campbell, sir? And Colonel Fowler?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Go! The agent lurches off. Brenner is charged, looks at Sunhi They’re getting close. EXT. BRENNER’S OFFICE - CID UNIT - DAY The phone is ringing. Brenner and Sunhill enter, he lifts handset.  71

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Brenner.

dialogues.speaker: HELLMANN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Colonel Hellmann. Brenner grimaces, looking at Sunhill.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: We’re almost there, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hellmann is in a seat with the air-phone, clouds piling p the window, turbo-fans droning.

dialogues.speaker: HELLMANN
dialogues.text: "Almost" is a subjective term, Mr. Brenner. The brass have reviewed your report. They don’t like the implications, and they’re getting nervous about leaks to the press.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What does that mean, sir? Hellmann sits next to Lt. Rogers who looks up from her la screen. Behind them, occupying the seats of the rear cabi five keen-eyed men in suits, CID veterans, all male, all

dialogues.speaker: HELLMANN
dialogues.text: It means that as of this moment you are off the case. You'll give your files to the incoming team, due to arrive in two hours. INT. BRENNER‘S OFFICE - CID UNIT - DAY Brenner grips the phone, the wind knocked out of him. Sun watches him with rising apprehension.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Colonel, we can give you an arrest in a matter of hours.

dialogues.speaker: HELLMANN, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: We have a major scandal here. This has to be handled with surgical precision. I can’t risk your track record.  72

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: My track record? I layed down for the Army, Colonel. We both know it.

dialogues.speaker: HELLMANN, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: It's a closed issue, Mr. Brenner. Brenner’s expression hardens.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. But let’s keep it clear. You‘re sending in a team of public- relations specialists, not a team of investigators. The line rings off. Brenner stands with the phone. He yan hard, ripping the line from the wall, throws the phone ac the office. It bangs into a wall heater.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: He cut us!

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Bastard! Specialist Dixon appears in the door, flushed with excite She looks at the phone, looks from Sunhill to Brenner, th eyes crazed.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Mr. Brenner..? We've recovered the hardware.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: It's a bombshell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenner and Sunhill lean over Specialist Dixon, the lit s of Campbell’‘s notebook computer before her.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Okay, Dixon. Detonate. Dixon scrolls columns filled with print.  73

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: We found her calendar. Names, dates and notations regarding sexual acts.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Which names?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: This is extremely embarrassing, sir. We have a number of references here. The individuals we’re certain about are Provost Marshal Major Kent and Chief of Police Yardley in Midland.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: And Colonel Moore at Psy-Ops, and the General’s adjutant, Lieutenant Elby.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Colonel Moore? And Elby? Brenner looks at Sunhill. Bang.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: (jarred) What do the notations say?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: They‘re pornographic, Ms. Sunhill.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Read Major Kent’s.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: Out loud?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: If you will. Dixon uncomfortably clears her throat.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: "Another sweaty fuck-session with Bill. Tied me to the bed, used the whip... Multiple orgasms. Made him eat me. I put the silly pig mask on his face. Enormous erection..."  Dixon scrolls, Dixon stops. He glances at

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two agents 74

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Ah-ha. One of those. Skip to the last entry. applies herself.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: It's Major Kent again... "Bill behaving like a love-sick jerk. Jealous, possessive, violent. Wanted to run away with me. I laughed. Struck me, tied me up, raped me on the floor. Think he’s going off the deep end.” She's a little overheated.

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: That's where it ends, sir. Sunhill. It’s looking very grim for Major Kent.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: What date is that entered under?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: August eight.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: That thing has a clock, doesn’t it? Something that automatically records dates and times for entries?

dialogues.speaker: DIXON
dialogues.text: It crashed.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: See if you can un-crash it.

dialogues.speaker: CID UNIT
dialogues.text: move toward the exit.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: We have the arrest, Brenner -- his bootprint, the computer entry. It hangs him.  75

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: We don’t have the arrest, Sunhill. We're officially sidelined. The glory boys are on their way, with Hellmann leading the charge.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: And you're just gonna let it happen? I thought you were the one who threw out the rule-book?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They burst out through the door, tempers ragged, move acr the hot asphalt.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: You’re a real ballbuster, Sunhill.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHTLL
dialogues.text: That’s right, Brenner. I’m not getting replaced by a team of stooges who think they can sweep this under the rug. Brenner finds his keys, rips open the door of the truck. stops behind hin. He stops where He jumps in. he starts it, the asphalt.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: We said we were going all the way with it. So get your ass off the sidelines, make a fucking end-run! he is, turns, eyes savage.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: You want an end run?!

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: That’s right!

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Get in the truck! Sunhill races around to her door, clambers in as exhaust rapping. The truck blasts away, smoking  76

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel Fowler, in battle dress, strides along a row of s colored Abrams tanks, howitzers, Bradley fighting vehicle *massive engines of war mothballed in the military drawdo Ahead, Brenner stands with Sunhill, waiting at the motor gate. They salute. Fowler stops before them, torso and ar filling out his shirt, eyes razor-edged.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: We have our man, sir.

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: Name him.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Major Kent. Fowler assimilates the information grimly. Beyond, a priv dutifully scrubbing out the chamber of a tank.

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: You say this understanding what my position is?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. You need to reconsider your position.

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: Why are we having this discussion, Mr. Brenner?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: You said if there was anything you could do, let you know. There is.

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Keep me on this case. Fowler considers him wordlessly.  77 INT. PROVOST MARSHAL‘S BUILDING - NIGHT Brenner and Sunhill enter the doorway of the Provost Mars office, a pair of MPs in tow. Cabinets, a wall of plaques awards, his desk, the chair behind it empty.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: He bolted.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Major Kent’s an officer in the Army. He didn’t bolt. The phone on the desk jangles. Brenner grabs the receiver

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Brenner.

dialogues.speaker: MP SERGEANT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Major Kent’s on the line, sir. Brenner nods to Sunhill, holding the phone. Kent comes on

dialogues.speaker: KENT, (V.0O.)
dialogues.text: I hear you're ready to close down, Brenner.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Where are you, Major?

dialogues.speaker: KENT, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: At the old infantry training field. I’m just kind of walking around out here. I want to talk soldier-to- soldier, Brenner. I'd really like that courtesy. The line clicks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Summer thunder rolls distantly. Brenner’s pick-up pulls u the edge of the field. The headlights remain on. Brenner Sunhill get out either door, looking across the grass. The throw of the lights graze a tall figure in a white he standing out in the middle of the field.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Don’t wanna spook him. Hang back.  78 Brenner stares out at Kent uneasily.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Unless he tries to kill me. Then don’t hang back. Brenner begins walking out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kent watches Brenner approach, his face even, stance rela He puts a hand out, motioning for him to halt.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: That's far enough. Brenner stops about forty yards from him.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: You armed?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: With what?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: With my weapon, Major.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Let me see it. Brenner sighs. He snaps open his jacket, exposing the but a semi auto in a shoulder holster.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Sig-Sauer Mll. Brenner studies him. Kent’s own sidearm is still buttoned his holster.  79

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: I stand by my Beretta M-9. It’s the most accurate piece I've shot. It’s ergonomic, friendly double-action, SA let-off is smooth, the sights are nicely proportioned... regulation is dead on... Kent eyes are on him, glassy, distant.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: It’ll absorb the recoil of a hot NATO-spec load with total poise. Brenner sweats, watching him. The man is over the edge. T thrum of crickets fills the humid night.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: That's really great, Major... Not many weapons can do that. He steps closer.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Just stand there, please... I have a few more things to say. His face is hollow and pale.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: I've been privileged to serve ina great cause. The Army has given my life purpose. I’ve loved it, fought for it, bled... Now I’ve dishonored it... I’m resigning my commission, Brenner. Brenner feels a ragged surge of pity.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: You’‘re doing the right thing, Major.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Don’t patronize me. You don’t meet the standards. Kent's eyes glare white in the headlights.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Easy, Major... Easy. Just tell me what happened that night.  80

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: You tell me.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: You met her on the range. It was her idea of a thrill. You’d done it before. But this time you lost it. It’s understandable, Major. She was dumping you. The tent cord ended up in your hands. By the time you realized it was around her neck... Kent shakes his head, his face broken out with beads of s

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Negative.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Come in with me, Major. Just unhook the sidearm. We'll make this easy. Kent grins, eyes ignited. Brenner wearily frees his pisto starting toward him.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: We're not going hand-to-hand, Major.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Before you walk any further, you should know where you’re standing.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Where am I standing?

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: In a minefield. Brenner frowns. Kent cracks his knuckles, face anticipato

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: I buried some Bouncing Bettys. Anti- personnel. You buy that?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Come on, Major.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Then you think I'm bluffing.  81 Brenner sees elation fill Kent’s eyes. He involuntarily s the dark grass around him. It is unmowed and thick enough concealing dug earth.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Remember how the Betty works? First man trips the primary. Mine shoots up. Rest of the column walk into the blast. Their heads are removed. Or limbs. Whatever. Brenner starts to move for Kent. Then he sees, just past reach of his headlights, the upright shaft of what could shovel jammed in the earth.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Come and get me, Brenner. I'11 wait right here. Brenner stares at Kent, trying to read him. There’s a cha the Provost Marshal is crazy enough to have planted somet dangerous in the grass.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE PICK-UP
dialogues.text: Sunhill is watching, adrenalin charged, unsure of what Ke saying. She has her gun in her hands.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE FIELD
dialogues.text: Brenner stands motionless, glances back to her, then at K

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: You could turn around. Walk out the way you came in. But if I am bluffing, you’re gonna look like a coward in front of your partner. He stands easily, savoring Brenner’s indecision, the fear is beginning to take root. Brenner begins walking toward him, his shoes crushing int grass. He moves with purpose, not looking down. Kent watc his every step with hollow glee.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: There‘s no mines, Major. You'd be in the kill radius, too.  82

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: I want to be in the kill radius. Brenner's gait slows. He stares ahead, the headlights at back. Sweat rolls down his face. Crickets hum.

dialogues.speaker: KENT
dialogues.text: Amazing what a load of shrapnel will do to flesh and bone. Take it clean off -- well, not clean at all, actually. You‘ve seen the casualties. Brenner wills himself ahead, nerves drawn tight, looking watching for signs of disruption in the grass. Kent is fr against the night, bathed in sickly light, growing closer smile goading Brenner. Brenner’s shoe hits something. He freezes. Fear pumps sha and instantly. His eyes bore into the grass, his foot rai half off the hidden obstruction. His chest constricts, his breath audible, swift. He remai still, blinking sweat out of his eyes. Kent's eyes are riveted to the grass where his shoe is po And suddenly the fear leaves. He sees Kent for what he is sad loser playing a loser’s bluff. Kent sees the realization pass in Brenner’s eyes. His goa smile disappears, stripped from him.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: It’s over. Brenner moves for him. As the weight of his foot comes do he feels it, just under the rise of ground, the steel of recognizes it, and is diving in a running leap even as it triggered, the primary charge cracking. The mine leaps up from the grass in a spray of sod. Brenn sprinting, skidding belly down in a headlong dive, the ni lighting up, the air rocking in a massive concussion, sha of shrapnel whizzing.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE TRUCK
dialogues.text: Sunhill shouts, her voice drowned, her face lit incandesc  83

dialogues.speaker: IN THE FIELD
dialogues.text: Smoke rolls, wet clay rains down. Brenner scrambles up to feet, eyes wild. Through the drifting smoke, Major Kent, still standing. B shredded, chest, arms, legs, face, perforated, blooming b

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: DON’T MOVE, MAJOR! Kent’s eyes are blank. He grins a ghastly grin and takes deliberate and suicidal step forward. The trigger plate snaps, the charge blows, the mine sprin and seems to hover an instant, black and deadly, hung in of his bloody face. Kent salutes it. He disassembles in a roaring flash of wh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four dour, experience-hardened military men sit in a row long walnut table, gaze harsh and exacting: Colonel Hellm blood in his eye. The Staff Judge Advocate for the Divisi The new Special Agent in Charge for Fort Hadley. And Gene Burns, Commander of the CID. The object of their gaze is Brenner, standing across from uncomfortably, the harsh light of the room in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BURNS
dialogues.text: It’s a grim outcome, Mr. Brenner.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: BURNS
dialogues.text: Grim. Deplorable. Bad for business. Brenner holds silence, anticipating being drawn and quart on the linoleum.

dialogues.speaker: BURNS
dialogues.text: Apparently your work impressed the Commander of the Post. General Campbell extended himself to keep you on -- he called his personal friend, the Chief of Staff of the Army... My boss.  84 He lances Brenner with his gaze.

dialogues.speaker: BURNS
dialogues.text: In effect, Colonel Hellmann was left holding his dick on the airfield. Brenner catches Hellmann’s stare, sorry he did. The Colon is shooting death rays.

dialogues.speaker: BURNS
dialogues.text: Did you have anything to do with this? You're on your oath. Four sets of eyes bear down on him. Brenner point-blank l

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: BURNS
dialogues.text: If I discover otherwise, you'll be out of the Army so quick you'll think you were shot from a cannon. Hellmann stares at Brenner unhappily.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Sir, has the objective of this mission been met? Burns considers him shrewdly.

dialogues.speaker: BURNS
dialogues.text: It has. Damage sustainable. I want to make this clear, Mr. Brenner -- you're walking a very thin line. I advise you to keep a low profile. Brenner salutes crisply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drab Army housing. Brenner stands at the open door of a r Inside, Sunhill is removing clothes from a rack in the cl He knocks, walking in. On the bed, a garment bag, a suitc

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: You‘re leaving?

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: I’ve been re-assigned.  85 Brenner tries to mask his disappointment.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Where are they sending you?

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Panama.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Panama? She looks at him unhappily.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Hellmann.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: My ballroom days are over.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Sunhill. I should never have let you come in on this.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: You couldn't have kept me out. She begins packing a garment bag.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: What’s going to happen to you?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: I guess I have a future. The upshot is, everyone’s relieved it didn’t hit any higher. She pauses in what she’s doing.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Brenner... I can't leave like this. She turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: This case still has too many pieces missing.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: I know.  86

dialogues.speaker: DIFFUSED LIGHT GLINTS
dialogues.text: Against white silk, Captain Campbell, like a goddess of w repose. Her golden hair fanned out, her skin porcelain, h eyes closed. Her snow-white waistcoat adorned with medals gold braids. Her hands clasped on the hilt of a gleaming Point saber.

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: In Isaiah, it was asked -~ ‘Watchman, what of the night? And the watchman replied -- ‘morning is coming’...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her flag-draped open casket, raised on a catafalque. Past a@ gathering five-hundred strong seated in pews, more spi out the doorway. Officers, friends, family, a limited poo print journalists mopping sweat in the sweltering closene the chapel.

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As soldiers, this is our calling -- to stand the watch each night, so that others may abide in peace until morning... General Campbell, Mrs. Campbell, stalwart and enduring, s the front, gazing to the podium where Colonel Fowler deli the eulogy, dress greens knife-pressed, his strong, comma voice ringing out over the hushed assembly. FOWLER (CONT’D) And we will stand watch until the day when it pleases God to call us into His Kingdom, and we need no longer stand the watch, nor fear the night. Further back, Brenner and Sunhill, both in dress uniform, patches, gold insignia, Brenner’s medals. Watching Fowler

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: Though Captain Campbell was mortal, and shed real blood, and shed real tears... She was a soldier first. Fowler turns to the casket, saluting.

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: Captain, that’s how we’1ll remember you.  87

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A volley of rifle fire cracks out. The firing party of se soldiers snap the bolts of their rifles, raise them again fire, repeat their motions, fire once more. Smoke drifts in the silence. Ringing the hot, green clear where the casket rests, flag across it, a huge crowd, hus A lone buglar takes a place near the six Army pallbearers color guard, the military band, the firing party. Heat po down. He raises his polished horn, sounds the first plain notes of taps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lined with buses, Army and civilian vehicles. Brenner mov toward Colonel Fowler who stands at his staff car, prepar to enter. He sees Brenner, pausing. Brenner snaps a salut

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Fine words, sir. Fowler nods his solemn thanks.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: I wanted to thank you for your help, Colonel. They observe each other.

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: A superior job, Mr. Brenner. Though I wouldn't want to be your CO. He allows a brief smile.

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: Do me a favor and don’t ask me for any more favors. He turns, gets in his car. Brenner watches it drive away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The operation is being dismantled, Seiver's personnel rap and expertly packing their gear, the slam and scrape echo  88 Seiver stands near the back of a van, supervising the loa of some lab equipment. He watches Brenner’s pick-up appro from one of the bay doors. Brenner gets out, walks over.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Something bothers me, Seiver.

dialogues.speaker: SEIVER
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: The final results on St. John’s and Major Kent’s bootprints. How come your expert never got back to you? They back away from the swinging end of a crate being hau into the bed of the van.

dialogues.speaker: SEIVER
dialogues.text: He did. This morning -- Be careful with that fuckin’ thing!

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: And you didn’t you notify me?

dialogues.speaker: SEIVER
dialogues.text: It’s completely immaterial now. Brenner stares at him edgily. Seiver regards him, mystifi

dialogues.speaker: SEIVER
dialogues.text: Jesus, Brenner. You slam-dunked the case. What’s the problem?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: What did you get, Seiver?

dialogues.speaker: SEIVER
dialogues.text: He examined the tracks. Says there’s no method of determining with hundred percent accuracy which came first.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: But he gave you his opinion. Seiver observes Brenner defensively.

dialogues.speaker: SEIVER
dialogues.text: His opinion is Kent arrived on the scene after St. John, not before. Brenner is stunned, Seiver’s voice distending, reverberat  89

dialogues.speaker: SEIVER
dialogues.text: I disagree with him. Major Kent did it. The proof was collected ina hundred yard radius on the infantry field...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenner, still in dress uniform, his eyes fixed on a prin on his desk.

dialogues.speaker: SEIVER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +++ SO who you gonna go with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The log of Captain Campbell’s calendar -- columns of numb dates, hours and minutes.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: looks up from the print-out.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: He didn’t do it.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, OFFICERS CLUB
dialogues.text: A noisy dining room filled with commissioned soldiers in colored battle-dress camouflage. Sunhill moves her tray a the cafeteria counter. Someone slides a computer case her way, she looks up. Bre has cut into the line ahead of her.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: He didn’t do it. Sunhill stares at him, caught off guard. His eyes burn ma

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: What? The officers in line are watching them. Brenner grabs her and leads her away.  90

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Brenner, what the hell are you doing? They move through the dining room, stop at the front door takes her arms, looking into her face.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: There’s a problem with her calendar.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: One of the entries was made about an hour after she was killed. Her expression falls.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Dixon logged the times and dates. I went over it. He’s still out there, Sunhill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They rush out through the front doors, muggy rain spillin the covered walkway.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: He knew about the basement. He knew she kept a calendar. And he knew he could frame Kent.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: (dismayed) And we bought it.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: He overlooked the automatic time- clock. He makes mistakes.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: We need a new motive. They move out in the rain.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: That’s your job. Run your theory -- the traumatic event at West Point. Plug into the Records Center, track this Army doctor down.  91

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Zaccardo?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: If he’s alive, get an airlift, talk to him face-to-face. Pull out all the stops.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: We have no time, Brenner. I’m out in two days.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: We go without sleep. He stops near his pick-up, slewed sideways in the parking

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Her lecture tape -- psychological warfare. Mindfucking. We’ll use it to level the field. Got a car?

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Contact me when you have something.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: I’m gonna start narrowing the list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car skids to a halt. Sunhill jumps out. A UH-60 Black H waits for her on the tarmac, props churning, lights winki crewman waiting at the open door. She looks at it, apprehensive, determined, then sprints t it. The crewman holds out his hand, she leaps in, the cho tilts upward, blades slashing the rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A drinking spot, cinderblock, a bunker. Brenner’s truck r into the muddy lot.  92

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Country rock on the sound system. Locals lining a dim, sm bar. Brenner walks in, carrying a briefcase. Scans the ro At a table in the back, Chief Yardley, chewing on a burge staring toward Brenner. He is seated with associates, men help run Midland and find themselves with little to do. Brenner arrives at the table, sliding into a chair and re his briefcase in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Hi, Chief. Yardley eyes the briefcase, then Brenner. He sets his bur down, formally.

dialogues.speaker: YARDLEY
dialogues.text: Well... Mr. Brenner. His associates regard Brenner inhospitably. A waitress wi lots of hair and curves moves up behind Yardley with a tr

dialogues.speaker: YARDLEY
dialogues.text: Fellas, why don’t ya‘’ll get a drink at the bar?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: They don’t have to go. Yardley stares at Brenner, surmising his intent.

dialogues.speaker: YARDLEY
dialogues.text: Proceed with caution.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: I’m in a reckless mood, Chief. Where you were on the night of August sixth between the hours of ten and twelve? Yardley inclines his head rearward.

dialogues.speaker: YARDLEY
dialogues.text: Donna, honey, tell Mr. Brenner where I was that night. She looks at Brenner with happy vacancy.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: In my muff.  93 The men around the table chortle. Yardley joins them, sha his head fondly.

dialogues.speaker: YARDLEY
dialogues.text: Ain't she a peach..? I‘m a bachelor, Mr. Brenner. Brenner unsnaps his briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Well, since we’re on the subject, I think Donna will enjoy these. Brenner removes a stack of photos, spreads them out like on the table. Yardley’s eyes narrow at them, then widen a registers their content. His associates crane forward to

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: The Yardley retrospective. Selected images. Donna leans over with her tray, her face stiffening.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Oh my God... Brenner slides one of the photos closer.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: This one’s my favorite, Donna. Check the paunch. She tilts her head to it, affronted.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: The paunch? The teensy erection.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: I think we have a tentative ID. Yardley glowers, his complexion livid.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: She had a camcorder in the basement, Chief. The lab printed these. They put you there. Withholding evidence. Obstructing Justice. Misconduct in office. Conspiracy...  94

dialogues.speaker: YARDLEY
dialogues.text: First thing, I got no idea what you are talkin’ about. Second, I don’t see anyone's face here.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Well, how you gonna see the face?

dialogues.speaker: YARDLEY
dialogues.text: Shut up, honey. You got squat here, Brenner. Goose eggs. Nothin’.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Ever hear of forensic anthropology? Yardley chews on his lip, glaring.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Forensic anthropolgy reconstructs the identity of a person through bone or body parts. What I’m gonna do is get a subpeona. Tell the Feds we need a shot of Chief Yardley’s penis. They'll come out with a camera. Then the lab boys go to work and match it. Brenner gathers the photos up, throws them into his brief slams the lid closed.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: You're through, Chief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenner stands out among the other parked cars, staring g at his truck. The windshield is smashed in, diamonds of g scattered across the hood. He turns around. Johnny Ray and Deuce slouch against the of a nearby Camaro, watching him with amused menace.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY RAY
dialogues.text: Peckerwood pick-up.

dialogues.speaker: DEUCE
dialogues.text: Rebel thunder-Chevy.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY RAY
dialogues.text: Looks like a break-in.  95

dialogues.speaker: DEUCE
dialogues.text: Call Nine-One-One. Johnny Ray wheezes a chuckle. Deuce leans to one side, bl a wad of spit.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Good thing you didn’t have your muzzle on. Deuce looks at Johnny Ray. He pushes himself off the Cama Tattoos, musculature, stripped to fighting trim.

dialogues.speaker: DEUCE
dialogues.text: I’m off the leash. Johnny Ray offers advice to Brenner from his indolent slo

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY RAY
dialogues.text: That's problematic for you. Deuce glides teward him. Brenner shifts his stance. Deuce eyes flick over him contempuously.

dialogues.speaker: DEUCE
dialogues.text: He's tired.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY RAY
dialogues.text: Give ‘ima rest. Deuce fearlessly plants himself across from Brenner, unli his legs in a little bounce.

dialogues.speaker: DEUCE
dialogues.text: Hey, Johnny Ray? You think he knows hand-to-hand combat?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY RAY
dialogues.text: Might. You just got to stay hard as white oak tree. Deuce’s eyes glaze psychotically.

dialogues.speaker: DEUCE
dialogues.text: Man down in parking lot.  96 He fires his leg at Brenner in vicious snap kick. Brenner suddenly holding it tight in the crook of his arm. He blu sweeping his own leg behind Deuce’s free leg and cracking point of his chin with a hard palm thrust, reaping the ma standing leg out from under him. Déuce slams the ground b first, his cranial nerves short-circuited. Brenner releases his leg, whips his pistol out, levels it Johnny Ray who rolls off the car defensively, his hand at rear of his waistband.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: You pull that, you're gone.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY RAY
dialogues.text: Fair fight, fair fight. The big man is half on the ground. He holds one hand out slowly places a pistol on the dirt with the other.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Now get the glass off my seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chevy pick-up rumbles up to the gate, windshield miss Brenner displays his badge as he drives past the MP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clamor of the monkeys rocks off the tiles of the room the lab bench, Colonel Moore, oblivious of the noise, abs in his work at a computer. The lights suddenly go out, plunging the windowless room darkness. The screaming primates fall silent. Moore, fram in the dimness, turns from his work. He looks past the ca toward the room’s entrance. Someone is standing there. A vague shape. Moore blinks, h lenses steamed in the close air.

dialogues.speaker: MOORE
dialogues.text: Who's there?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: The grim fucking reaper.  97 Moore stares into the blackness, uneasily, his glasses li the sickly green light of his monitor.

dialogues.speaker: MOORE
dialogues.text: Is that you, Brenner..? Moore hears a steel latch rattle. The monkeys begin howli rocking their cages.

dialogues.speaker: MOORE
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: I‘m letting the monkeys loose. Moore face drains.

dialogues.speaker: MOORE
dialogues.text: Have you gone insane?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: How would you know? The monkeys fall silent again as hinges squeal. Moore’s e widen sharply.

dialogues.speaker: MOORE
dialogues.text: Those animals are rabid! Moore lurches from the bench, trying to feel his way forw

dialogues.speaker: MOORE
dialogues.text: Brenner..? I'll have you up on -- A rhesus screams, hurtling from its enclosure. A projecti of hair and muscle that rips past Moore’s face, dislodgin his glasses. The shape tears across the lab bench, toppli his monitor and vanishing. Moore gasps, his glasses dangling. He freezes, eyes blind searching the dark. A savage shriek pierces his ear, Moor screams, a set of fangs rush out of the dark and snap at He stumbles along the bench, flailing, trips, goes down t knees. He brings his head up. A set of red eyes blink at from a cage inches away. A low, lethal chatter commences. hears the cage latch click.

dialogues.speaker: MOORE
dialogues.text: Enough! Brenner’s voice is very close.  98

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: You were there on the firing range, Colonel! You helped stake her out! You hid her clothes on the latrine!

dialogues.speaker: MOORE
dialogues.text: You can’t do this, Brenner! It’s a violation of -- Brenner grabs him by the shirt, hauls him to his feet, sl him against the bench, eyes murderous.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: You‘re up to your ass in this! Start talking! Moore sags, resistance crushed.

dialogues.speaker: MOORE
dialogues.text: Ann required... bold remedial therapy to address a longstanding... and unresolved issue that was destroying her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A block of run-down storefronts, iron-grated windows. A t cab pulling up to the curb. Sunhill gets out, pays the dr and looks to the entrance of a seedy clinic: Dr. Joseph Zaccardo - Foot Surgeon Medicare and Most Insurances Accepted

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunhill is shown inside by a tired, obese nurse who close door as she leaves. Sunhill takes in the room; an exam be blistered walls, a foot chart. Not a going concern. The door opens. A black man enters, referring to a clipbo He glances up at her, sunken-eyed and aged hard.

dialogues.speaker: ZACCARDO
dialogues.text: Ms. Sunhill. I’m Doctor Zaccardo. Apparently you have some sort of an emergency today?

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Yes.  99

dialogues.speaker: ZACCARDO
dialogues.text: Remove your shoes, please. Sunhill kicks off her flats. The doctor leans down, exami her feet, his spidery hands manipulating them.

dialogues.speaker: ZACCARDO
dialogues.text: Actually, you have exceedingly sound conformation.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Actually, it’s not my feet. The doctor’s eyes peer up at her from great dark circles. complexion gray, unhealthy.

dialogues.speaker: Z2RCCARDO
dialogues.text: Explain, please.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: I'm here to talk about West Point. Zaccardo straightens up. He stares down at her.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Nineteen-Eighty-Six, Doctor. You examined a young cadet. Her name was Ann Campbell. Zaccardo’s face closes on her.

dialogues.speaker: ZACCARDO
dialogues.text: I have no memory of her. I examined hundreds of cadets when I was at West Point. As you can see, there’s been quite an interval since then.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Captain Campbell was murdered at Fort Hadley, Georgia five days ago. Zaccardo moves to the door.

dialogues.speaker: ZACCARDO
dialogues.text: I have a busy schedule.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: I need your help, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: ZACCARDO
dialogues.text: Who are you?  100 Sunhill stares at him, desperation rising. She’s losing h

dialogues.speaker: ZACCARDO
dialogues.text: You're an investigator? Fine. I'll call my attorney. He begins through the door.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: I hope he handles malpractice. Zaccardo stops in his tracks. Sunhill blinks, stunned by she’s just said. And it keeps coming.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: I'm here for the plaintiff, Doctor... Who asserts Captain Campbell’s death was a direct result of the trauma she underwent at West Point... He turns back to her, fear flickering in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: And unless you can convince me you were under orders to destroy her medical files, we’re slapping you with a multi-million dollar lawsuit. The doctor stands uncertainly, staring at her. Sunhill op her purse, removes a folded report. She unfolds it, readi

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Campbell, Ann, Grace. Cause of death -- asphyxia. Aside from ligature on neck, no trauma to exposed tissue, or to bones, brains, mouth, vagina... She pauses, her emotions rising.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Some erosion of the cervix indicating a prior disease, abortion. Stomach, bladder, intestine contents analyzed, toxicology clean. No drugs, poisons, alcohol. Trace fluids analyzed. Perspiration... Tears... She looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Tears running downward from the eyes.  101 Zaccardo moves to the counter, seems out of breath. He le there, not facing her.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: This was a human being, Doctor. She was crying when her life ended. And she was crying when she came to you, ten years ago. He remains immobilized against the counter.

dialogues.speaker: ZACCARDO
dialogues.text: There's nothing I can say that will help her now.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: You can tell the truth. Zaccardo slowly turns. A man who has buried himself alive

dialogues.speaker: ZACCARDO
dialogues.text: It was so long ago... I was sworn to secrecy. You have to understand. It wasn't easy, getting a position... He stares into the past.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Why did she need medical assistance? ZACCARDO’S eyes catch the sun, the broken weave of his irises, the b holes of the pupils.

dialogues.speaker: ZACCARDO
dialogues.text: She was raped... The blackness enlarging, becoming

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: A place and time ten years ago. A place of summer heat. D trees ringing a view of the sky. The shrill of crickets. muted sound of struggle.

dialogues.speaker: ZACCARDO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Gang-raped, on a training maneuver...  102 Fireflies trail past. Coming into clarity below the trees assembly of shadowed faces. Brutal, youthful faces, conce by camouflage netting and crazed stripes of greasepaint. glinting whitely, holding lust, violence.

dialogues.speaker: ZACCARDO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Eight cadets... They bound her with tent cord... One of the faces leans in, close, a cadet, eyes fixed, br catching in his throat. A young woman’s cry rises, exhaus tortured.

dialogues.speaker: ZACCARDO, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Left her bleeding in the dirt.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE EXAM ROOM
dialogues.text: Zaccardo stares, eyes fixed. Sunhill is moved to rage, te She fights it, trying to keep her voice even.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: There’s... no record of the charges.

dialogues.speaker: ZACCARDO
dialogues.text: She never filed charges.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Why? Zaccardo looks on her.

dialogues.speaker: ZACCARDO
dialogues.text: Charges would have lead to a court martial, and a court martial would have dishonored... the institution. So far as the United States Army is concerned, it never occurred.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: And the cadets who raped her?

dialogues.speaker: ZACCARDO
dialogues.text: Never identified. Men who’ve become one thing or another, blended anonymously into military or civilian life.  103

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Was it Campbell’s decision not to pursue a court martial? The doctor regards her bitterly.

dialogues.speaker: ZACCARDO
dialogues.text: Which Campbell, Ms. Sunhill? She stares at him across the dingy room, the silence swel EXT. BRENNER’S TRAILER - WHISPERING PINES - DAY Rain streaking down. Brenner’s pick-up drives up through mud, stops near the front of the trailer. The windshield been replaced. Brenner gets out, his eyes on something. Parked across the yard, a staff car. Someone behind the f of the window. The driver’s door opens and Colonel Hellma stands out. He stares across to Brenner.

dialogues.speaker: HELLMANN
dialogues.text: The case is closed, Mr. Brenner.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: I have evidence that says otherwise. Hellmann walks toward him.

dialogues.speaker: HELLMANN
dialogues.text: Major Kent is guilty and a military court will make judgment accordingly. It’s a done deal.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: You may not want it go any higher, Colonel, but it does. The rain sweeps the yard, streams down Hellmann’s deadly

dialogues.speaker: HELLMANN
dialogues.text: Let me walk you through this: The sole purpose of the military is to serve this country. Your purpose is to serve the military. Unconditionally. Without question. Brenner stares at him.  104

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Just like Fort Belvoir, Colonel? Hellmann takes him in, his trailer.

dialogues.speaker: HELLMANN
dialogues.text: Look at yourself, Brenner. You never really knew what being a soldier meant. The investigation’s over, the best interests of the United States Army have been served. Their eyes are locked.

dialogues.speaker: HELLMANN
dialogues.text: Have we reached an understanding?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Fuck off, Colonel. Hellmann springs for him. Brenner ducks his fist, pinning forcefully to the pick-up. He restrains him, Hellmann pan in rage, teeth clenched. Brenner releases him. Hellmann jerks away, eyes blazing. stabs his finger out at him, growling.

dialogues.speaker: EHELLMANN
dialogues.text: I’m giving you a direct order! Drop it! Disobey, you’re finished! Hear me? Finished! He moves back, angrily straightening his sodden blouse.

dialogues.speaker: HELLMANN
dialogues.text: And Sunhill’s finished, too! He throws open his car door, glaring, gets in, slams the rams the car away, tires spinning. Brenner stands in the rain, face dark, watching the car s out of the lot.

dialogues.speaker: THE SOLDIER
dialogues.text: of plastic is silhouetted against the lowering sky, face and expressionless, standing eyeless sentry.  105

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenner, eyes haunted, stares up at the target’s hollow f He turns from it, looks down to a chalk outline fading in dirt, all that remains of Captain Campbell. The pavillion gone, tattered strands of police tape strung forlornly ac the area. Beyond him, Sunhill approaches from the road. He looks up her as she stops across from him. She has been without sl looks drawn, but resolute.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Captain Campbell was gang-raped at West Point. There were no charges, no trial. The crime was buried. She was sold out to avoid a scandal. Brenner computes this information grimly.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Who was the broker?

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: The broker was her father... She’d been waging a war against him ever since. He demanded a cease fire... Her eyes fall to the chalk outline.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: This was her answer. A reenactment of the night she was raped. She looks up at Brenner.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: He sacrificed her. For the good of the Army. Summer thunder reverberates softly. They stand watching e other, the sky hanging heavy and hot.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: You did good work. He takes a pocket-recorder from his jacket.  106

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: This is Colonel Moore’s. He came out here with her, helped her set it up. Then he called the General's line at HQ and left this message: He snaps the recorder on.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN CAMPBELL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: This is your loving daughter, daddy. I have the answer to your ultimatum. I’m at Range Six. Surrounded by a compliment of very dashing soldiers. Don’t keep me. Her tone sugar-coated, chilling. Brenner snaps it off.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: I checked the phone records. The call was received.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: The General lied when he said he had no contact with her. He came out here. When he saw her like that...

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: We don’t have a match on his boots.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: He gave us another pair.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: I don’t think so.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Motive, opportunity, the will to act. It's all there.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: You're really gunning for him.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: How can you stand there and defend him after what he did? You really are all in the same club. Brenner scowls, insulted. She regards him, her nerves fra  107

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Change of Command's tommorrow. I don't want to lose this.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: You have lost it. The Army’s pulled out. We're out here on our own with zero authority. She studies him, understands the edict has been handed do

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Are you bailing on me?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: It's a suicide mission. Always was. Let it go. Take your transfer, put it behind you.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: What about you? The rain breaks, hot silver flashes.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: I’'m going down anyway. You don’t have to go down with me. He turns his collar up, moves for the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He strides below the tower, rain drifting. Sunhill jogs u

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: I’m not turning my back on this. He makes no response. She takes his arm, they stop under steel stilts of the tower, face to face.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Don’t walk away from me. We/’re in this together. We’re gonna see it all the way through... I want that sick son of a bitch. Brenner considers her irately, makes a decision.  108

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Okay. You‘re gonna get him. I’m gonna give him to you.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: You have a strategy?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Yeah. All or nothing... Be at the parade field tommorrow morning. He turns without another word, moving through the rain to road. She stares after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A phone is ringing. Fowler stands before a mirror buttoni his parade blouse. His wife appears with a cordless phone

dialogues.speaker: WIFE
dialogues.text: Chief Warrant Officer Brenner. Fowler takes the phone.

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: What is it, Mr. Brenner?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Sir, we have proof Major Kent didn’t kill Captain Campbell. Fowler pauses, frowning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenner, in a gray suit, holds the phone, tense, listenin

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Where is this going?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: In a direction you won’t like, sir. It looks bad for General Campbell. Silence on the line.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Colonel..?  109

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I’ve heard you.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: If this is going to be handled right, I need your assistance, sir.

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: (warningly) Mr. Brenner, General Campbell is my closest friend. Brenner stares through the glass. Sun-splashed lawn, the shout of a drill sergeant.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: No, sir. The Army is. Where can we we meet privately?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A block-long, weathered wooden structure, long ago abando Brenner’s truck moves across the weed-cracked asphalt, co to a stop. He gets out, scanning the area. He sees no oth vehicles, walks toward an open door ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands inside the doorway. Ahead of him, a long room, and shadow, the floor strewn with debris. He moves forward, the planks under his feet creaking, sag rottenly. In the dimness, a briefcase resting on an old t and a figure taking shape in the dark beyond it.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Colonel? The shape steps forward. Colonel Fowler, his face coming the light. Parade uniform, ribbons and metals, a belt wit scabbard, the silver hilt of a saber.

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: What do you hope to accomplish with this meeting, Mr. Brenner?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: You helped me once before, sir. I'm relying on you to help me again.  110 Fowler stares across to him.

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: According to you, my help resulted in the arrest of the wrong man. Brenner holds his stare unwaveringly.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Exactly, sir. You helped keep me on the case. To arrest Major Kent. And Major Kent was framed -- set-up. The percussion of military drums floats from the parade f

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Are you with me so far, Colonel?

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: I'm riveted. Please continue.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: By your own admission, you ran a surveillance of Captain Campbell. You knew everything. Major Kent was prime to take the fall. Fowler stares at him, his eyes deep, black, like starless

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: When the General delivered his final terms, she sent back her answer. He left his office at twenty-three- hundred. At twenty-three-o-four she rang in. You picked up the call.

dialogues.speaker: HEADLIGHTS
dialogues.text: on Rifle Range Road, pulling in behind her humvee. They s off. Darkness.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The General’s protector. Forty years together. Braving wars. Slaying the enemy. She was enemy... And she was winning...  111

dialogues.speaker: AT THE BERM,
dialogues.text: Fowler's grim face beneath the roiling sky. Heat flickeri

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So you drove out to the range and you annihilated her.

dialogues.speaker: LIGHTNING FLASHES,
dialogues.text: showering light.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: staring up, eyes widening in terror. Flooding with tears. shadow blocking them.

dialogues.speaker: THE CLOUDS
dialogues.text: churning in fury, rimmed with electricity.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN CAMPBELL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Father... Her voice lost in a clap of thunder.

dialogues.speaker: THE EYELESS FACE
dialogues.text: of the plastic pop-up soldier. Merciless. Empty and blind

dialogues.speaker: IN THE BARRACKS
dialogues.text: Fowler’s face beneath the rafters, the same eyes. Brenner standing across from him.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: You strangled her. Fowler is still, watching him. He speaks finally, voice h

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: Captain Campbell was a disgrace to the uniform she wore. Whoever the executioner was, he did the Army a great service.  112

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Is that your confession? They stand silently in the dim, dusty light. A soft click heard. From Brenner’s jacket pocket. Fowler nods toward i

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: I think you ran out of tape. Brenner scowls, his eyes falling to his pocket. Fowler st toward the table where his briefcase rests. Brenner puts hand near his weapon, ready to draw it.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: That’s far enough. Fowler stands motionless. Brings his full, commanding gaz Brenner.

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: Captain Campbell is dead and buried, Mr. Brenner. But you and I are part of something that will never die. We continue. The General continues. We're pieces of the same machine. His eyes bore into him.

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: I'm putting a letter of commendation in your file. As you’ve seen, I have influential connections. You can get your Master Grade. The respect and prestige that come with it. All you have to do is just turn around... and walk out. Brenner watches him warily.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: A bribe, Colonel?

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: A reward. For a job well done.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: No deal.

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: Then you've chosen the alternative.  113 He has a black pistol in one black-gloved hand. An Army-i Beretta that freezes Brenner's own hand at his lapel.

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: Use that hand to remove the tape recorder, Brenner slowly does so, caught by Fowler’s stealth and sp

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: Toss it to me. Underhand. Brenner underhands it. Fowler catches it, his weapon stea He steps to his briefcase, opens it, drops the recorder i

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Now what?

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: I shoot you. With Lieutenant Elby‘s weapon. Then I return it to where he keeps it. He’s been under a lot of stress since you linked him up to that basement sex ring. Brenner is coiled, intent, waiting for the slightest chan vip his piece out and fire it empty.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: It won't fly, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: No one knows we‘’re here, Mr. Brenner. And I’ve arranged an emergency for Lieutenant Elby. He’1ll miss the ceremonies entirely. As for myself, I was in full view of four thousand troops when he shot you. Brenner's arm flashes, his weapon halfway out as Fowler’s cracks twice. Brenner, taking both shots in the chest, ki backward, lands on his back, the rotten planks caving in him, his body crashing through the floor. Dust billows. Fowler moves over the hole in the boards. H sights rest on Brenner, sprawled on his back in the filth the foundation three feet below. Still as rock, mouth gap eyes glazed, two black holes blown into his jacket, nearl center and close together.  114 Fowler’s gun slams, the muzzle blast lighting the dark of foundation, Brenner’s body jolting as the middle of his s explodes into white tatters, the ejected shell tinkling a the boards. Fowler admires his marksmanship.

dialogues.speaker: FOWLER
dialogues.text: One-inch group. He steps over the broken planking, grabs his briefcase, w swiftly out the barracks door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Campbell gazes out over the companies of his divi assembled in formation, rows of bright flags shimmering i windless heat.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: I stand here an old infantryman, with a soldier‘s love for the Army. It’s grandeur. It’s ability to make heros of common men and women whose service is given in faith and courage... His words ring over the field. He wears battle dress, a b with a holstered pistol, a blouse filled with medals for campaigns. A line of senior officers stand behind him, Fo among them, his saber hilt glinting.

dialogues.speaker: CAMPBELL
dialogues.text: We serve something much larger than ourselves, and to serve it, we must hold it dearer than our own flesh and blood. We are bound together, as only warriors can be bound... I have given my heart to my country, and my service to it will never end. The General turns. The color sergeant formally offers him division flag. The General receives it, turning once more solemnly confer it upon the new Commander of the Post, an chain of command continues unbroken. The General salutes him, relinquishing his position, and his salute to his troops, his face held rigidly against t There is a deep and awed silence. The General steps down the platform, in majesty and sorrow.  115 A great cheer erupts from the companies standing in forma Thousands of voices raised up in heartfelt farewell, an u that rocks across the still afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunhill stands at her car above the field, anxiously sear for Brenner. She holds a cellular phone, the dialed numbe display, the line audibly pulsing.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Come on, Brenner...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brenner’s truck on the hot asphalt, the phone unit on the pulsing, light lit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The broken flooring. In the dimness past it, propped agai the wall and in considerable pain, Brenner. He is shirtle streaked with dirt and sweat, grimacing as he tears loose straps of a Kevlar bullet-proof vest. The vest slides off, three black impact marks dented into heart region. His chest is bruised, ribs broken. He hears Phone pulsing faintly, turns his head to the open barrack door, his truck visible past it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunhill, frustrated, stares at her phone, the line unansw

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Damn. She disconnects. EXT. BRENNER‘S TRUCK - BARRACKS 5 - DAY Brenner leans out of the open door, thumbing the phone on bringing it to his ear. Dial tone.  116

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunhill moves away from her car, stalled, anxious, lookin some sign of Brenner. Her beeper goes off, she turns, spr back to her car, dives for the phone.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL
dialogues.text: Brenner..? EXT. BRENNER’S TRUCK - BARRACKS 5 - DAY Brenner, breathing in pain, is sitting behind the wheel, in hand.

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Oh yeah.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Where the hell are you?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: (wincing) Listen to me. Find Fowler’s car. Look for his briefcase. Moore’s tape recorder should be in it.

dialogues.speaker: SUNHILL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Fowler?

dialogues.speaker: BRENNER
dialogues.text: Then find the General. That’s where Fowler will be. I’m on my way. He disconnects, fires the engine, slams into gear, scorch off across the asphalt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trunk of Fowler’s staff car. The rend of metal, the t lid popping up. In the well of the trunk, Fowler's briefc A soldier with a slide-hammer moves back. Sunhill stands the open trunk, staring in.  117

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A vast green floor studded with columns of distant soldie olive and tan. Tiny, colorful flags. Brass glinting from military band, the remote sound of horns and drums. The f lined with grandstands filled with civilians.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The parade march coming in louder. The General’s personal on the lawn below. A group of ranking officers gathered t bidding the General and his wife goodbye. Recognizable wi the gathering, Colonel Fowler, shaking hands. From the tan width of road below the officers, a figure m across the grass toward them. Sunhill, her stride determi The parade drums thundering, beating out a martial cadenc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunhill approaches the group, stopping a dozen feet away. by one, the officers turn to her. Stillness falling over as the General walks out to meet her. They exchange words. The General turns to where Fowler st but Fowler is no longer there. He turns back to Sunhill. drums reverberate. She raises the tape recorder. The Gene stands listening to the playback. Sunhill turns the recorder off. The General, staggered, w away from her. He drops to his knees. The rumbling percussion fades out as a great, anguished s rises up, shaking the air. EXT. BRENNER‘S TRUCK - EDGE OF PARADE FIELD - DAY The pick-up slams to a skidding halt, Brenner bails out, shirtless, weapon in hand. He races past the crowd that p out on the field, soldiers and civilians staring, shoutin in alarm.  118
